In Africa the problem is much more complicated and you could use an egoistic argument as a counter argument to this video. If one person of a poor city or tribe plants some seeds so he can eat the food that grows out of that seed and he notices the advantages he creates. And because of the fertile soil in Africa he could plant seeds on a much bigger scale and make a farm out of it. So just like we did in other prosperous countries. The problem here is not that they aren't able to plant seeds and create agriculture and farms, the problem here is the mindset of the rest of the people living there. If you tell people working there 'if you work ten times harder tomorrow I will give you a 5 dollar bonus', so you give them the 5 dollars because they worked harder, you would suspect that they would start working harder because they noticed that they would earn more. But no because of their mindset they just don't show up the next day because they need to spend that 5 dollars. If someone builds a farm or creates proper agriculture the rest of the people just take what they can get and move on, they don't think ahead like we do in the rest of the world. That isn't racism, it's just their education, they got that mindset from their parents. That's also why they were never able to step out of their lifestyle after they got so much money, support and help from other countries. From the moment they stop helping Africa, the people living their will just go back to spend what they can spend and eat what they eat. “If you give a man a fish, you feed him for a day. If you teach a man to fish, you feed him for a lifetime", in Africa that would say: "If you give a man a fish, you feed him for a day. If you teach a man to fish, he uses the fishingrod to make a fire". that's why they will never come out of poverty and the famine will keep existing.

Germany is one of the best examples. 1.) Development of China: now Mercedes and Volkswagen have their biggest markets in China. Far bigger as the European markets could have ever grown. We helped them grow. Now they are our customers. And we buy cheap products in China. 2.) Eastern Europe: all the investments into the economies of eastern Europe already paid off. Again creating customers and also many production sites moved there. Initially this was thought to be an issue. But today we know: we would never have enough work force here, to serve all the needs. But there is one issue with the whole argument: the positive sum game is only possible because we are exploiting natural resources. And that possibility will come to it's end. Either we develop more advanced technologies that help us to further grow without destroying nature or that game will come to a halt.

Now, the whole premise about the world having become a positive-sum game is a complete lie. Earth is basically a zero-sum game in terms matter and in itself a negative-sum game in terms of energy. The energy coming from the sun is what keeps us at a zero-sum game energy in the long run.

So the whole economic growth thing, with the pie getting bigger every year for an infinite amount of time, is simply a lie.
The pie (physical resources) never gets bigger, we have and can only become better at transforming resources into forms that are more useful to us, but the sum in the end is still zero.
The illusion of evergrowing economy is only made possible by the disconnection between the physical pie (wich is fixed) and the virtual pie (wich can in theory grow indefinitely because it's not real nor connected to the physical pie). But at some point the virtual pie will have to come back to the reality of the physical pie.
That is why the world economy is surerly going to collapse hard at some (very near) point, because the amount of physical resources never grew, it couldn't.

We can't physically have an evergrowing closed system. We can make things way more efficient so that less resources are needed to accomplish the same thing, but even efficency have a physically unsourmontable cap. Once that point is reached, equilibrium, or stability is the best possible condition, the only other possible direction is regression.

Notice that God has intentionaly been kept out of the reasoning to keep the whole argument in the natural order of things, the one kurtzgesagt is interested in.

I really like a large part of the message of this video: that the world is a positive sum place, and benefiting others is generally a key part of any effective strategy for benefiting yourself. I think that's great. Technically, though, that isn't altruism. Helping others isn't even the essence of altruism. That is a common misconception. Actually the essence of altruism is self-sacrifice. If you benefit others while benefiting yourself at the same time, that is by definition not altruistic. Hence egoistic altruism is an oxymoron.

Benefiting other people is great, as it truly does make the world a better place for you to live in, again generally speaking, depending on who you're helping or in what way you're helping them. For example, benefiting others who are trying to actively harm others in turn does not make the world a better place. Nor does helping others who only seek to take advantage of your benevolence so that they don't have to lift a finger to help themselves, and can live purely at the expense of others such as yourself. That's because these forms of helping others are not positive sum. They are just other ways to have a relationship where one person wins and another person loses, except that you aren't the beneficiary. As a consequence of such relationships, the value gained for some people comes at the cost of value lost for other people, so that there is no net gain, and the world as a whole does not get better. It is also important to point out that not only does helping others often benefit yourself, but harming others comes at a terrible inherent cost to yourself: making enemies. And when you can benefit yourself by helping others instead, while having a much greater potential to create friends in the process, the choice is obvious.

Given these basic facts about human relationships, one should ask a more basic question: why is it necessary to think of benefitting others as an end in itself in the first place? If everyone can build positive social relationships on a selfish basis, then people do not have to think of others first in order to have a cohesive and healthy society. If one wants to take some time, even the vast majority of one's time, or all of it if that was possible, to benefit oneself without effecting others one way or the other, would that be wrong? If you truly respect and love yourself, you should understand that other people are a value *to you*, and that is the whole point of having relationships, hence it is a tragic mistake to put those relationships, or the well being of others, ahead of your own well being. You deserve to be the primary focus of your efforts. Of course if you are morally consistent, you should recognize that other people likewise are entitled to benefit themselves, and since it is in their interest to do so in a way which does not harm you, and they are smart enough to understand that, there should be no cause for distrust or resentment. To live your life for your own purposes, alongside others who are doing their own thing with your blessing, is the true nature of partnership.

Altruism, as the morality of subjugation and sacrifice as such, is an old, mistaken idea, which unfortunately has the weight of a lot of moral tradition, including religious tradition, thrown behind it. It isn't necessary at all. In fact it is quite destructive, and should not be the basis of moral judgement or aspiration. As fast as the world has grown over the last few hundred years, it could grow so much faster if the people doing the work of growing it were better motivated and if they believed in themselves, instead of having their spirits depressed by the belief that they owe their whole lives to everyone but themselves. Slaves do not make good workers. Without the ability to benefit from their own efforts, they lack the proper motivation, and their work suffers. The same is true for those who are enslaved in spirit, who though they have the legal right to enjoy the fruits of their own labour, lack the self-esteem, the sense of moral entitlement, to do so committedly, proudly, and unapologetically.

All this talk about industrial revolution and innovation but not a word about what makes this possible, that is, energy?? Come on kurzgesagt, I thought you had higher standards. You're missing the one big massive and only elephant in the room here!
All the economical development since the industrial revolution is entirely due to the discovery and consumption of coal, and later oil and gas. More specifically, it is due to the high EROI (Energy Return on energy Investment) of these energy sources. Many studies focusing on the link between energy and economics argue that our modern lifestyle in western countries would not be affordable if the EROI of our energetic system would go below ~10. Most renewable energetic systems (photovoltaic, wind turbines, biofuels) currently have an EROI that is smaller than that. Keep in mind that for intermittent energy sources, you have to include all the storing devices and processes in the loop ; for biofuels you have to include the low energy efficiencies of plants photosynthesis and agricultural practices.
Innovation, research, technology development are just a byproduct of the energy profusion that we've been enjoying for 200 years, and more specifically, fossil fuels that inherently possess a high EROI.

This video leaves out a very important fact: increasing production year on year globally is simply unsustainable. It requires the environment to provides raw materials and the waste products go to landfill while side effects compromise clean air, water etc - the things that are essential to life but outside the economic system.
My opinion:
We need to go to a closed loop economy where we produce new things from recycled materials and at the end of their life they become input to something new.
We need less consumption, not more. It isn’t making us happy. Minimalism is a great way to live, possessions just weigh you down.
We need to use renewable energy sources. Phase out fossil fuels ASAP.
We need more co-operation and less competition.
We need to be nice to each other and remember that human connection and intimacy is really the most important thing. You can have all the material goods in the world but without it your life will be empty.
So yes it is important that everyone on the planet is doing well, but not by simply increasing everyone’s spending power. What matters is the health and fulfillment of each person and the planet herself.

There are some major logical flaws in this theoretical concept of growth, which is based on certain presuppositions, which are not explicitly expressed before or after the video. Firstly the logic conducted here is based on the assumption that there is infinite growth. This is a major flaw, since its conflicting even with "kurzgesagt"'s own videos about the climate change. Nothing in nature is infinitely growing or has an unlimited lifespan. Since the human race is a part of nature, they are also bound to these laws. Secondly and this in line with the first flaw, there are just not enough resources for all countries on earth to reach the development of the highly industrialized countries. Thirdly and this is the saddest part about this is the presumption that class is completely ignored in this video. It is highly likely that almost all people on earth want the same stuff we have in our first world, but there is an interest of the ruling class to actually keep many people poor so they may fulfill the role as an industrial reserve army or a labour force reservoir to exploit as the bourgeois sees fit. The major caveat here is that incentive for innovation is not always driven by personal financial gain. There are a lot of reasons why people look for better solutions to existing problems or for new solutions to as-of-yet unsolved problems, be it a desire to make an existing solution less of a burden to the inventors or innovators, to find a way to save more lives, or just because the inventors and innovators have a genuine passion for the subject matter. The rate of innovation is also not strictly dependent on the number of wealthy patrons you have, though more funding never hurts, the biggest bottleneck to innovation and invention is the number of passionate people you have working on the project in question. One of the very first professors I had in my engineering undergrad told us the story of a European inventor (whose name eludes me as of this moment) who had major funding from several nations to invent the world's first heavier-than-air flying machine. When he read in the paper that two bicycle shop owners in Ohio had done it first, he just quit, because the reputational and financial incentive were gone. No one is going to get rich off of being the second person to invent the airplane, so he didn't bother. The lesson that our professor was trying to tell us is that two people with little to no funding but a lot of passion for the subject will outpace a single person with a lot of funding but little to no interest in the subject matter beyond what they can gain personally from it every single time. So while more wealthy patrons can drive progress to an extent, they are far from the only drivers of progress

This idea works only if everyone is playing the same game to achieve a positive sum existence. An attempt to meld games with disparate rules and goals would probably generate more conflict than innovation. For everyone to abide by the rules of a positive sum game, philosophies about how the game should be played would be suppressed, and a domineering philosophy would be inculcated. Or, a peremptory incentive that transcends political and cultural norms has to be instantiated such that following any philosophy other than a positive sum game would be a blunder. Eventually, only one philosophy would take control to dictate the rules for a positive sum existence.

It was always a Positive sum game, the main difference is the positive sum is growing exponentially like our population. If you look at the rise and fall of empires throughout history you'll see this. As empires rise the overall standard of living increases like with the Rise of the Roman empire. But then something happens, usually some greedy people in power who treat it as a zero sum game or just to lazy to contribute but just wants to take what they want.

Eventually the Empire collapses either from outside invaders or internal revolts and most people end off worst off. It's only seems like it was a zero sum game to the untrained eye because the overall pie on the average slowly increased due to the constant rising and falling of empires since a years of growth are then offset by years of decline. After all some of the most successful empires in history revolved heavily around trade because they benefited from specialization which is something that contributes to the positive sum game.

What about climate change ? 🌎 I understand the general argument and mainly the fact that if people around the World become better off, they will have more access to education and then contribute to global innovation thus improving our live + the fact that this would also increase demand for things we want and thus also increase incentives to innovate. But when we know that GDP is directly linked to Co2 emissions, if billions of people in developing countries reach today's standard of living in our developed countries, we are doomed to worst climate scenarios..

I'm not saying that the poor should stay poor because of that, I think that Climate justice is essential and that developing countries should be allowed to keep growing till all humans leave poverty. But the only way to do that while mitigating climate change is if developed countries accept DEGROWTH.. and I believe that most citizens are not ready to sacrifice their comfort..

even if more people better off would mean more education, more research, more innovation to fight climate change and maybe new solutions, the problem is the temporality of those effects. Increases in Co2 emissions will happen directly while the benefits of innovation would happen in decades..

so in conclusion I think there is a flaw in your argument : not taking into account temporality and phenomenon like climate change but we could also think about depletion of resources.. a material infinite growth is impossible on a finite planet.. at some point the pie won't get bigger and it would be a zero sum game again

This ignores the greed of the industry. While the argument is laid out great, the reality looks way more grim: Innovation needs resources; It's great if you can pay for 7 times as much, but at the same time there must be produced collectively 7 times as much. However, there are only so much resources on earth, distributed over countries. Countries that have different cultures and different levels of development. One needs a minimum level of development on a country wide scale to be able to use these resources according to the context of the video. However, in a less developed country the mentality might be like this "If I work hard, I can barely survive here. If I work less, rich people will come and give me money...". While I am well aware, that this is a provocative argument and not many people think like this, it is sufficient if the right people there think like this. Donald Trump is a perfect example of such a man in power, that does not share the same thinking as the majority of the FIRST WORLD  country he is ruling. Further more, the pie increases each year, yes, but not equally! If you have a lot of land (referencing the picture in the beginning of the video), the pie stack is bigger in volume than when you have less land. Thus, wars for resources are still a thing and robbing and plundering happens now less visible on Wallstreet. Patent law and lobbying are major factors too and the focus or universities is shifted from "push our knowledge further" to "push economic interests further". While I, myself, would strongly support an idealistic world, where everyone is better off and knowledge is SHARED instead of monopolized, I see this only possible if the way of thinking of people in general changes and I don't know how we should achieve that on a grand scale... People are selfish creatures on a primal level and only few are able to stand above their feelings.

While I fully agree on the idea to make this a better world, it is sometimes hard to decipher what makes the world a better place.

It is sometimes hard to because we are more and more living on 2 sides of the world, the optimistic and the critical side. Considering all, like racism, economics, politics and even psychology. People at this time feel down and I feel that a lot of people like to live in another timeline. It's sad, especially at this time, it's like people don't appreciate their people or their surroundings.

From personal growth and so many other things. Things that surround us like racism, economics and politics shouldn't be a burden. It's from the people, especially the ones who try to make it better by discussing it. It's just that some topics are not worth talking about. It sometimes makes things worse. A thing I'd like to say, is to delete words from our dictionary. To just not think too much about it. Racism is a good example, it's common language and 'it happens'. We all are picking favourites, we 'all' are silently judging if someone is a 'rotten character'. Racism is nothing but basically that, calling a character 'rotten'. If it's true? We don't care. A fine line in a definition like racism, should be: "The way to have a reason to hate someone just by a stereotypical or characteristic representation." That should be the definition of racism, nothing more. Preferably I would like to erase that term, but therefor I need confirmation and conformation. I don't know if that is possible.

But people like to define things. Sometimes further and further and sometimes we need peace. A piece of a critical but optimistic observation. Peace in mind is sometimes much more worth than discussing all that matters. Both things makes us unite, but both things are also separated.

Always try to consider the fully opposite. I know it can be hard, I know you'd like to dedicate fully (at least I like to), but when it comes to knowledge, it may be a lot worth. When it comes to peace? There is a slight risk to it ;)

The poorest man in the US has it eons better off than the poorest man in an underdeveloped nation.
Now, while this video shows the positive side of human cooperation and culture, it doesn’t take into account serious economics or even socio-cultural issues as they inevitably appear throughout the course of generations. We’re entirely ignoring the political side of innovation, ignoring monopolies, ignoring shifting balances between capitalist tyranny (for a lack of better words) and socialist/communist subjugation. All of these factors contribute to stagnation, corruption and greed, etc. in moderate amounts, they are negligible, as a matter of fact, this video inspires greed through the lens of selfish altruism; but excess corruption can seriously debilitate a nation and collapse of a proper familial structure spells the end of a civilization. We shouldn’t dispel the idea of a second dark ages too quickly, despite how unreasonable it sounds. But the world is not a pretty place, not everyone knows that. This video is entirely predicated on the presumption that none of these factors tilt the balance of power too far in one direction or the other, and off the very faith we have in western civilization to continue existing. No one knows whether that’s true or not.

The first time I heard the term "Egoistic altruism" was in a story called "The fable of Abraham Lincoln and the pigs". The story goes something like this: "Mr. Abraham  Lincoln once remarked to a fellow-passenger on an old-time mud-catch that all men were prompted by selfishness in doing good. His fellow-passenger was antagonizing this position when they were passing over a corduroy bridge that spanned a slough. As they crossed this bridge they espied an old razorbacked sow on the bank making a terrible noise because her pigs had got into the slough and were in danger of drowning. As the old coach began to climb the hill, Mr. Lincoln called out, “Driver, can’t you stop just a moment?” Then Mr. Lincoln jumped out, ran back and lifted the little pigs out of the mud and water and placed them on the bank. When he returned, his companion remarked: “Now Abe, where does selfishness come in on this little episode?” “Why bless your soul, Ed, that was the very essence of selfishness. I should have had no peace of mind all day had I gone on and left that suffering old sow worrying over those pigs. I did it to get peace of mind, don’t you see?”

I agree with all of that, but there is one thing that contributes to the number of reasons that makes poor countries stay poor, which is the barriers to entering a matured market domain.
For instance, a poor country would need to produce value added products to increase its growth but developed countries would be producing those products already, on a large scale, long before them which decreases the unit costs as well. For instance, there are limited number of cell phone companies. USA, China, S.Korea dominates the global cell phone market. Even developed countries like UK, Germany, France can't enter those markets because of the competition.
This situation makes them stay poor if they have not enough natural resources. They can't invest in education, healthcare systems, infrastructure, etc.
One option would be to let foreign firms create businesses inside your country to use the cheap labor, so the country can increase its tax income, and can learn related technologies from those firms by observing, faking, or by agreements. But this not efficient for poor countries, imo.
I think some countries will stay poor for decades, and the economical gap between poor and developed countries will only increase.
This would also cause migrations as well. Because nobody would want to live miserable just because they were unlucky to born in a poor country.
It is, indeed, in interest of developed countries to help poor countries to grow. Give education, share technologies, spare some fundings.
I don't have high hopes of the future though. The leaders have the mindset of 19-20.yy, and they are uneducated. The global warming will cause millions to die and force people to migrate. The global economy will take a huge blow like never before. I would expect wars on top of that as well, because the free falling economies may force some countries to take actions in their economical interest. Wars for clean waters, fertile soils, energy etc. I know that developed countries can't risk nuclear wars with each other but that won't stop them to use other countries as proxies to wage wars.

Positive sum game, eh? Well that’d be nice. Far from true, though. All of the advancements and privileges (that some can “enjoy”) described were paid for by the exploitation of natural resources and essential eco-services (upon which our existence depends) that are declining and disappearing. The big picture is no different than it was before the industrial revolution- we have merely discovered more, new pie (fossil fuels) and are still stealing from our neighbors as well as from our descendants and their future neighbors. Our ”game” wont last much longer at this rate. Usually I enjoy Kurzgesagt and find it insightful, but this episode is appalling in its forceful rejoicing of affluence over its silence on the truths of affluence’s reality and costs. There will be no better world, there will be no world at all, unless society addresses its underlying exploitations of others and nature.

Though I support the goal mentioned : global and inclusive innovation and prosperity, the portrayal of past versus modern economics is too shallow and partly false. Resources on Earth are limited and we therefore have a serious issue facing us now and international competition is still very steep at the moment. Yes, international cooperation and sharing/trade will help us all for sure, but claiming that reality went from zero sum to positive sum is a gross exaggeration or rationalization. It is more about how our worldview or attitude aims more towards a positive sum Humanity. As resources are limited, and all billions of people in Humanity cannot suddenly eat tons of meat and drive cars, we certainly need innovation!
- No, we cannot just make countless pies without consequences. All in all, education, innovation and being ingenious will greatly reduce the current ecological crisis.

That whole cancer argument is incredibly naïve. Sure, it might be in an individual's best interest to not have cancer, but curing cancer itself is not so far from curing death. Even the simple function of removing one of the largest death-factors in the Western world would exponentially increase the population, thereby diminishing the quality of life for everyone. Additionally, the matter of funding is more complex than whether or not researchers have funding. Many researchers don't have adequate funding, but at the same time, many other researchers have an over abundance of funding with which they do nothing but fill their own pockets. This latter sort of researcher often has many friends who write positively about one-another in scientific journals and who take the part of peers in peer-reviewed research. They are incredibly corrupt and benefit the world comparatively little.

Instead, pharmaceutical companies should invest in producing drugs which alleviate symptoms, but do not get rid of disease, so that you one can have a continuing customer base.' you can think of Martin Shkreli for a high profile example of this type of vulture capitalism in the pharmecutical industry, although this is just a drop in the bucket. Our economic lords often promote the idea of 'win-win' economics, when in fact the business model usually is to produce problems which then they can fix and charge you money for. I feel the major flaw with this one is that, while we all benefit from the poor farmer in the example getting help, it doesn't actually matter which of us individually are the ones to help them. The benefits of everyone being better off are universal but the costs of getting there aren't. Thus, while the ideal is that everyone pays into it, if you really wanted maximize your individual profits, you would want to be the one person who didn't therefore reaping all the benefits while paying none of the costs. And, naturally, because the profit incentive is to not pay, nobody operating on a purely Egotistic basis* would and the whole concept of Egotistic Altruism crumbles.
Don't get me wrong, I see what you're trying to do and I appreciate it, but the premise is flawed.

*Unless there's such a thing as an Egotistic Collectivist, maybe? I don't know, I don't like the idea of that. It makes my brain uncomfortable.

Deal is: There are consequences to everything, and in trying to be altruistic, you may actually be contributing negatively. Just for one example, the massive sums of used clothes just dumped on Africans means that their textile industries are being competed with by literal free junk. Even if they wanted to, it's not really possible to work for less than free. They are being hampered by the pampering.

You can also look at the water charities. It's a lot more appealing to a bleeding heart to see that 1,000,000 villages have been granted water by this charity than 1,000 villages. Problem being that often times, because it's not as cash efficient, training people to maintain the pumps isn't actually done, leaving the cheap water pumps to break down after a year. But if they slowed down and made sure they sustainably deployed their pumps, and bought better pumps, then the number of villages supplied drops, and so do charitable donations. (Also, they'd quickly start to run out of villages to water, meaning that they've worked themselves out of existence.)

Instead, what should be the focus is bringing safety and stability to the nations. Stability brings investment, which, by definition, are expected to be more productive than their inputs. This makes the fates of Africans more self-determined than by force feeding them free stuff that teaches a sense of helplessness - a dependency upon someone else. This lack of self-direction leads to violence, and destabilizes the region.

They got two things wrong. 1) the world has never been "a zero sum gain". Innovation has always happened. As a matter of fact, it happens at an exponential rate. However, this means that it starts small, then starts to get big. This is because the more things there are to draw knowledge from, the faster we can think of things. The more we can connect ideas, the more we can find the best ideas. But new ideas don't come out of nowhere, thus it takes time for the amount of ideas to increase. 2) Their description of economics has the right idea, that demand and free market leads to innovation, but its watered down in a way that makes central planning seem like a good idea. That is a problem, because central planning attempts to take away personal demand which leads to 1) slower innovation, and 2) doesn't meet personal demands. So when they say 'imagine how much farther along in cancer research if more people could pay for it' isn't exactly an accurate statement because the ability to pay for something doesn't determine the supply. Say a million people were to pay one dollar for cancer research, the funding would only be one million dollars, thus they only get a million dollars of benefits. But if only ten people were to pay a million each, they would get ten million dollars of funding, thus they would get more benefits. They ability to pay doesn't speed up the process.

However, there is a single serious error in reasoning.
Way of life in developed countries (energy, industry, manufacturing) is overwhelmingly unsustainable. If you wake tomorrow, and every person on the planet is living with the standard of Italy, Croatia, US or Germany, our planet resources would be depleted in a matter of years, and pollution would skyrocket, making it impossible to live anywhere, making any future progress impossible.
Opponents of this way of thinking would say that more people working on sustainability issues would mean we find solutions faster, and it is true. There is, however, a very real possibility that by spreading unsustainable technology too fast, would simply shorten our planets 'habitability lifespan' by too much and would fail to solve sustainability issues by the time resources run out.

I am kinda disappointed that you missed this crucial angle of the story.

I would say the processes of open competition in the open/free marketplace have driven innovation in almost every sphere of human development.

Indeed, our resources may be finite, but the method of their effective application, which derives from human ingenuity and experience, is almost infinite.

This is why Thomas Malthus (overpopulation theory) and other sincere, but single minded idealists were debunked time and again:

They operated from a "ceteris paribus" standpoint, which is not accurate when describing the universe, which is in a state of perpetual flux.

However, it is tempting, especially as an intellectual, to extrapolate an existing trend into infinity, especially when one is accustomed to dealing with concepts and variables strictly or generally in the abstract.

Please don't skirt over the claim that we live in a "Positive Sum" world. Its borderline absurd. There is no positive sum world we consume resources at an increasing rate so it SEEMS like it will last forever. Countries like AMERICA need to decrease consumption on a per capita basis to sustain it! Factoring in obvious things like climate change, if you are going to claim that our current economic system in most of the developed world is also going to fix our problems, you need to consider the reasons it created them in the first place.

 Furthermore, the increase in consumption and production under capitalism has not benefited the classes equally. It actually furthers class divides and reduces equality. Evidence is present day Lords like Jeff Bezos being more powerful than any nobles in the feudal era! Its the main problem and its not getting fixed by capitalism! Its an externality of Egotistic Altruism, which is designed to solve externalities.

Final point, if you have a theory for how our current economic system can overcome its biggest problems, it has to be possible in that economic system. If egoistic altruism existed, would capitalists being doing it? They certainly pretend to do it but it ends up looking much less... altruistic than egoistic.

Well, let me think about it
Industrial Revolution: STONKS

"More people could have more at the same time?" - So, the industrial revolution created more pie? I don't really get that concept. If the world of today is not a limited pie, why is it necessary for Adidas to produce in Indonesia and not in Germany? And why does GMC have issues when Toyota sells more cars in the US? People only buy as much as they need, the pie therefore is necessarily limited just as the funds of companies, people and countries are. Also thinking that the world staganted until the industrial revolution is totally ahistorical. And even sun energy is limited, there is a limit of watts per square metre, regardless of how much we wish for more. Technical progress didn't make the pie bigger, the pie just got more modern in comparison, but it is as limited as before and always will be. Once Indonesians want the same amount of money from Adidas German workers want, Adidas will actually produce in Germany and Indonesians will have no jobs. Same with pretty much any other industry.

It could be argued that, contrary to what the sponsors of this video want to convey, the principles of egoistic altruism transcend the confines of the capitalist system. If everyone innovated for innovations sake, we would all reap the fruits of new technology without the need of a financial incentive. Empowering scientists then equally distributing the products of their labour among the populace would be a more direct approach, rather than supporting the bourgeoisie establishment in the hope they invest their pot of gold in mutually beneficial industry (rather than short sighted oppression as is more common). The means of transitioning from our current state to such a system is where I would disagree with most communists and anarchists.

I have loved this concept of egoistic altruism for some time, but a lot of people make the mistake of thinking our current neoliberal capitalist system runs under such a principle, which is just as much a facade as our class system being a meritocracy. Left to their own devices, most capitalist decisions of investment have no such foresight, seeking only immediate returns in profit at the cost of the worker, consumer and environment. Monopolies and built-in obsolescence are the bane of an innovative, post-scarcity future.

The industrial era didn't change much: wealth is still concentrated in very few, who aren't kings or emperors, it doesn't mean that they don't affect the management of a country or that they have no influence on how they are governed. Social rights and benefits have been based on social revolutions, and there are even societies that still exploit the worker under the excuse of "development". What really changed is the social order, democratic societies began, and in practice, they had little democracy: women couldn't vote, they had no right to study or develop as a person, the poor became even poorer because  of industrial exploitation, identical to how they approach it at the beginning of the video with the explanation of the cake. In countries like Chile, workers weren't even paid with money, but tokens were used that only served to exchange within the place where they worked. Perhaps those that I emphasize isn't so visible today, perhaps they will be able to say that at least it has been improving. But under what consequences? Repercussions that continue to this day when they see that in highly developed societies they don't have sufficient social economic security to defend themselves against a virus. Despite all the scientific and technological development, the economy that dominates and is based on industrial development, remains precarious due to the economic concentration in a few. All of the above has to do with the type of economic system related to the industrial period. What changes, apart from the economic one that has benefited a small group of people, have been thanks to the industrial era? The positive was the development of the sciences, but if we take a detailed tour of human society, not much has benefited for collective development. Because although we look at our cities and their buildings, cars and their great growth thanks to that "economy", it is still an unequal and unfair system. It always privileges a few at the expense of many.

With a lack of industrialization, Tsarist Russia was an agriculturally-dominant state. Once the Bolshevik Revolution happened - the USSR greatly industrialized. Becoming a superpower that matched the US in 20 years while the USA took 200+ roughly, and was the first into space in 70 years while the USA horribly followed. Now healthcare is free in Cuba, Socialist Germany (DDR) was the first to heavily introduce safe-sex practices. All these socialist states showed great promise and conditions. Despite all this immense success of socialism, backwards people still say it "failed" all the while it is arguable to say that the USA could have failed from the same effort the west had at destroying the USSR but reversed.

Another, simpler way to put this idea is: if more people don’t have to worry about, for example, health care, they’ll feel freer to spend their money on goods. This will produce more work, providing more will for the workers, which will inevitably works its way up ad nauseum. Trickle down is a lie: wealth doesn’t flow down from cups that never get full. But wealth climbs very well.

While this video is right that supply is often dependent on demand, it should not be forgotten that the basic concept of economics is how we deal with the allocation and use of limited resources at our disposal. Meaning that if we were to put more resources toward one area to better it’s development, we would have to take those resources from another area. As we are trying to work along our production possibilities curve, and can not magically create new resources except through advancement freeing them up.

There has been a real world example of the effect of the Positive Sum game.

After WW2, the world is divided between the communisitic Soviet Union and the capitalistic USA. Many countries, especially ones closer to the borders of communism like Germany, Korea, and Japan recieved great financial aid under the Marshall Plan from the US. The intention behind the plan was to make the country stay out of Communism, but the bigger side effect was the Positive Sum game the video mentions. These three countries mentioned soon grew into the top rank countries in terms of economics. We have German engineerings and cars. We have Korean K-pops and Samsung. We have Japanese trains, and of course Anime and Waifus. Without such aid, we will never see German engineering and cars, never see K-pops and Samsung, and will never see Anime and waifus. Just imagine what other countries could innovate if they were simply given the aid.

We live in a world where “goodness” is thought to bring you up and help yourself. Being a lifelong Christian and conservative, my opinion on this matter is quite different. Yes, Capitalism drives us to innovation and we all benefit from it, sometimes leading all to greater increase in wealth, or as the diagram illustrated it, an increase in pie. However, there is no good from which bad does not come. For a business to thrive and increase in power and income, there has to be another business which dies out. This is the glorious business cycle and how it should work. The way this relates to goodness and being helpful to others is an important one. Spreading the message that God has sent Jesus Christ to accept our sin and die for us is the ultimate happiness for me, for I am boosting my faith while bringing others to God to have life after death. The competitiveness of Capitalism is great because it lets us all learn and help ourselves, boosting the American economy and boosting our own self interests. We all need to be good to others, but we do not only feel good from profit. We show others the ultimate sacrifice of our Lord and how he has given us amazing things. Getting two businesses to thrive does not work in the pong run, and one has to succeed. This is always a learning experience, and every person who tries will succeed in the long run at least once. God bless you all, and let us thank God for allowing us the freedoms to rule ourselves.

I don't agree with the trail of thought.
In reality as the demand for the same thing rises it's price rises which would be okay as everyone gets richer.
On the other hand, this video says that if more people work on something (7 times more) then the production would increase 7fold. This looks good on paper but in reality this is not what happens. As more people work on something the output of each individual decreases because of the size (administration, communication, worker motivation etc.). This is the basic idea of economy and it has been proved in many cases. After a point the added value of 1 man is close to 0. This mechanism is constantly dropping the wages (as worker supply rises) and after a certain point the people cannot buy what the rich can and they could earlier.


Even if you don't agree with this argument, there is another reasoning. The "production of things" (most of the time) depends on materials. But materials (iron, litium for batteries, helium etc.) are not endless. If we keep expanding without borders then the price of these things rises more quickly (because the demand rises for it and it is getting scarce faster) and then the poor cannot buy those thigns once again. (And I haven't even opened up the conversation on what this does to the climate.)


All in all, there are some true points in this story but it doesn't takes into account the damage we do by expanding products to everyone (resources run out faster) and some economical mechanisms. Also some other things are also needed (laws, barriers) which prevent us from eating up everything this planet has to offer. Without these steps their argument cannot become"true".
Their argument also makes the assumption that if more people work in science then the solution is closer. But in reality we do not know the technologal boundaries and this might not be true. (We might never be able to jump in time even if we work on this for a milion years with billions of people.)


PS:
I agree that we need to make the world a better and more balanced place though based on another argument.

Just saying, this is a very Eurocentric view. There are routes of education and knowledge of place and space that is more valuable to human health and safety. This knowledge is often inside the minds and hearts of Indigenous people all over the world. People who love and respect the land understand natural patterns, locations, and resources that are most valuable. I get that conquest and theft makes the convenience simpler to achieve, but we should also take the time to value every form of knowledge so that we can advance technologically, but not do it at the stake of Earth's health, or minority wellness. If we advance too far technologically, the balance of Earth's atmosphere can be offset, causing a negative reaction even if we can't see it right away. Climate change is an example with flash floods, drought, tornados, earthquakes and more all increasingly occurring after we began to mine and frack for fossil fuels. And the decrease of health and safety policy surrounding people of color, as we are the ones who have been most impacted by loss of biodiversity and resource value; and are navigating the system of federal policy to change our conditions.

Also, some people enjoy simplicity. This life is unfair with politics, it transfers power. But everyone has their own power and every little action taken from planting a tree, to buying a biodegradable product in a supermarket is a way of grasping our power and changing the world.

My suggestion is: rather than conquering the world as a major power source, we first, collaborate with people, understand their needs, educate the minority population about the various opportunities that could be available and we benefits. Then, we can customize the products produced based on their Intergenerational wisdom and geographical region.

Everyone deserves a good education, clean water, clean and nourishing food, and healthcare....but we all have different needs, and sorry to say, but the specific ingredients in a European diet does not nourish the body in the same way for everyone which can cause disparity in health and wellness. I can tell you that as an Indigenous person, I wish I had the knowledge of my ancestors of what to eat off the land to cure my symptoms, because our people ARE doctors...as well as engineers, mathematicians, etc. We have developed knowledge over centuries of time, and though our history may not be as clear cut, it is there. It is wrapped in who we are. And I would rather try to understand my own identity, history, and culture than ignore it and fill my life with substances (drugs, alcohol, prescriptions, toxins/pollutants). Food is medicine. Hy'sxw'qe.

All I'm saying is to look at each individual in the world with a sense of compassion and curiosity to define what is considered beneficial.

Destroying land to get what we want and what we THINK we need, is less important than actually making a stable environment for us to live in, among other species that we care about.

I'll start with the factually wrong before I get to the things about this that are morally repulsive. One: there is no linear relationship between money spent on research and innovation. If the old image of the lone genius scientist inventing a flying car in his basement was wrong, the modern idea that science is a commodity produced in labs like cheese out of a dairy is even more wrong. For a variety of reasons, most labs produce junk science. The science that isn't junk mostly has very narrow applications: for example, a specific drug alleviates specific symptoms of a particular disease in some people. Most science of that sort doesn't lead to any broader understanding of the universe.
Some labs do good science, consistently, and that's why we have amazing technology. But ten times the money and ten times the number of researchers doesn't = ten times the science. It maybe results in 1.1 times the science. Which doesn't mean it isn't worth the investment, necessarily, but don't expect these new labs built in countries with endemic corruption to cure cancer.
Now to the evil part. The industrial revolution instantly made everyone's lives better! Who knew? Not the people who were literally enslaved by it, from the enclosure acts to the guys who were forced at gunpoint to work in coal mines until some time >after> world war 2. This video perfectly describes the moral justification social darwinists use for screwing over everyone else. Well done, Kurzgesagt.

Egoism places the value of your life (and everything that entails) as paramount to yourself. Altruism places the value of your life as irrelevant, so that your purpose is to serve others (which leads to sacrifice). Problem is that the invested money gets lost along the way. The more you invest, the more expensive a product/service becomes. Its nice to theorize about this ideal world, but when the 1% keep skimming all the cream of the top, there will never be enough cream for the less fortunate. So, you end up becoming just as competitive and selfish as the people you despise in order to take what others worked harder than you to produce. It is true that all the new technology and science does eventually make its way to the mainstream consumer, but it happens at such a slow rate that innovation outruns deployment which ends up causing increased income inequality. Trying to leverage it back into balance is really hard and can lead to critically stable economic models. How do you put a monetary value on productivity? How can two people who work the same hours and deliver the same amount of end product not receive the same monetary compensation for their effort? One is just better at negotiation and as such is promoted faster than the other, even though both deliver the same results. If both were to receive the same promotions, the big boss would just increase the selling price of the business offers. This loops back on the workers and now they have to work harder just to sustain the same level of living comfort. Then we account for automation and the internet where everyone becomes more diverse, so now people get laid off simply because the business no longer requires their inputs. These people could start their own businesses, which then encourages competitiveness and selfishness. The world no longer cares about whether a person's needs are looked after just for the sake of it. There are always strings attached. Make your workers happier because then they will give you more effort and you can exploit them further.

I'm not sure I would call pre-industrial civilization a zero sum game, at least not completely. If you live on your own, you have to worry about defending yourself, feeding yourself, housing yourself, and finding a partner (ok so you can't really live on your own, whatever). Live with a tribe, you still have to do a lot of those things, though friends and family can help. Bigger tribes become more efficient, each person is safer and better off than they were in a smaller tribe, because they have a lot of people that can defend against attackers, raid others, and gather resources. As societies build, less people need to be dedicated just to farming, because now you can have people whose job it is just to count food, do finances, and so on. You don't industrialize, but you do invent tools. Societies can also improve human output through motivations, from the nice (honor and caring for your community), to the neutral (profits) to the immoral (slaves are very motivated). You can spend less time defending yourself and more time farming, and people who are good at certain tasks or enjoy them more have more freedom to do them. Yeah this sounds a lot like the industrial revolution, it's the same kind of progress, just far smaller.


I say this because it's also my argument in favor of immigration, against the idea that jobs can be "taken". If it isn't true that additional members of your society creates a net gain, a net increase in wealth and happiness, then trading and civilization itself wouldn't have happened. At least, that's what I think, but I'm by no means some Jared Diamond type. Also nothing I'm saying disproves or goes against what you're saying in this video, I'm just nitpicking. Comparing the level of progress of most of civilization to everything we've done after industrialization is crazy. The exponential growth in everything is so rapid that our society struggles to keep pace.

Thank you Kurzgesagt for showing people how the masses of poor people escape poverty. By spreading the free market to other developing countries and having good education, billionaires will have a vast untapped labor force. Just look at what is happening in India right now. The free market and big tech companies establishing IT centers in India coupled with their culture, which puts a high emphasis on education (gurus are treated like extra parents [also, look it up]) has caused India unprecedented growth at about 7%. Also, when foreigners visit, it also helps the economies of developing countries for street vendors and other sellers to sell foreigners their goods and increase demand for them. This is why war and oppressive Communist and Fascist governments have high poverty rates and very little visitors from foreigners from most countries. Focus more on increasing the size of the global pie than trying to get somebody else’s or trying to exclude another group from accessing the pie due to arbitrary reasons (race, gender, orientation, etc.). This is why consumerism is good (so people in poverty can start buying goods and products in ever increasing amounts) and the ordinary guy should have an impact in the economy rather than a small group of people (who think they are above humans) deciding what the people want in a planned economy. Planned economy = economic dictatorship; free market economy = economic democracy.

Whenever I get into any conversation involving economics (not something I start usually, since economics is one of my numerous kryptonites) I always preface it by saying "if anyone tells you they understand economics, they're either lying, generalising, or are delusional." This being because economics as we understand it from a historical perspective is a very new invention which was not actively intentionally created, and is still in the process of development. What we have are general schematics of how such an organic, free-flowing entity works, and no one can fully comprehend it enough to make solid future predictions.
What we can say though, are things like Kurzgesagt has stated here. Modern economics works off of the basic principle of (seeming) indefinite expansion. The way to get ahead is to expand, and part of that expansion in a global system of trade is to make sure other people are expanding too, thus allowing you to profit from their expansion.

The only real issue I have with this video is that it doesn't mention the bad side of innovation. Here's a well-known example:
In 1938, everyone, from the Western Parts of Alaska to the Eastern Parts of Oceania knew a war was coming, and everyone knew this war would be the deadliest war in human history, a war so deadly, that it could cut the world population in half. Most countries did not want to stomach such a high cost, so some scientists in Germany decided to look for an alternate solution, to allow their country to win the war at a relatively low cost to their population. That year of 1938, they split the atom. 7 years later, a bomb was created that could destroy an entire city in a few seconds. They called this bomb the Atomic Bomb. The selfish demand for a weapon that could save a country's men and women in the armed forces from death, within 4 years after it was initially used, would turn into a weapon that could kill every living thing on the Earth.

This is an overly simplified stance, in practice it doesn't work like that. So what you've done is compare historic practicality with a contemporary idealism. The argument you made, which many people are iterating in chat by quoting Adam Smith, Ayn Rand assume that a free market can exist without any political or ideological interference. But it can't - because the powerful always gain if the system stays distorted.

In reality, the size of the pie is indeed increasing as you argue, but a disproportionate share of this increase is being accrued to those who already have the largest share of the pie. This is reflected from the fact that income inequality is rising, not diminishing.
Source: Oxfam Report, World Inequality Report.

So while you might argue that the poor earlier had one slice, but now they have two. It doesn't really help them because the difference is rising. 1 Pie could've fed me few years back, today that might be (Money is after-all purchasing power, so a x% increase in someone's income is useless if the cost of living goes up by 10x).

The reason I feel this is an oversimplified stance is because "Egoistic Altruism" attitude doesn't care about the collective commons like, for instance the Environment. You are unnecessarily relating 'Innovation' to 'Greed'. Greed is literally destroying the planet. Innovation can't save us if if it removes the impetus to reform our consumerist ways and rethink our relationship with nature.

The reason you're oversimplifying is perhaps because these things aren't quantified. There has been a longstanding demand for moving towards 'Nature Capital' or incorporating green capital in our GDP estimates, but no real progress has been made in this regard in our political discourse which once again points to the fact that Egoistic argument doesn't work - because those who're getting the biggest share of the pie want to make sure that the system remains rigged.

A message for every socialist:
 A monopoly is detrimental only if there are unnecesarry regulations. A true monopoly in a free market is possible ONLY IF the company offers best products in the lowest prices. There can not be a situation when someone achieves a true monopoly on his product without providing the best option for us. That is extremely hard to achieve but theoretically possible. The reason why you might think the monopoly in a free market is harmful is that you think we have anysort of a free market. We do not have it YET, maybe some day. There is always bunch of smart people waiting to make money. You just can not bother them to grow (only some basic regulations,). That is the first argument why everybody should be clever. There is only one danger, when the product is harmful: that is when people are too ignorant/stupid to notice that it hurts them. Even if the market clear itself, some regulations are necesarry to ensure people that every new product is SAFE, right? We don't have time to test everything. So we don't accept harming products, we should require the information about the composition of the product and his production process, environment and make tests for contamination. But that's all. LET PEOPLE GROW, do not disturb.

The funny thing is, it is selfish in a sense. Except within this context the self would be humanity. As we endlessly pursue innovation and improvement we learn more about our own limitations, thus more dissatisfaction, more "negative energy" is created as contentment and happiness is replaced with feelings of inadequacy and drive for better. We are destroying every corner of our planet as a result of this. Sure, we are becoming more conscious of this self-destructiveness, and as we "progress" we are getting better at treating the earth. But how many plastic islands, polluted waterways, extinct species do we as humans have to go through to fully understand the nature of balance and consequence? Will we ever be happy and content on this path of endlessly fixing every wrong, be it self-perceived delusions, societal demands, or suffering? Mankind has only inhabited this rock for a fraction of the time life has existed here, and life has seen millions of years of success. Not as a result of pursuing some ideal reality where everyone gets pie, all life ever did was simply exist, and allow the randomness of the universe to take course. Negativity will always exist, as is the nature of our world, a cup can never be seen as full if we cannot accept its state of emptiness.

"Egoistic altruism" is invalid at the conceptual level; that is, whoever the author is, is attempting to force together two contradicting concepts into one—an impossible aberration. To be altruistic is to negate oneself per Compte (the happiness of others); to be egoistic is to promote oneself (the happiness of oneself)—one cannot be non-contradictory by negating oneself and promoting oneself simultaneously.

To be an "egoistic altruist" is to dictate, "I both negate and promote myself at the same time, in the same respect" which is a violation of the fundamental principle of logic: A is A, and, A is not non-A. Something can't be two things at once, something is what it is, A is A. In effect, egoistic altruism is fundamentally the same as proclaiming, "I am both a positive and a negative"—it is impossible, you are nothing.

Egoistic altruism is an invalid concept; it's referents cannot "mix"—it doesn't exist.

This presentation might be the first one I take issue with:

1. Purpose: This argument for humanity fails to account for basic human nature that must be adjusted on a social level before its premises can be effective -- that is our tendencies to quickly abandon altruism once we've found a modicum of abundance for ourselves. A tremendous subcategory of this is often the search for a "forced multiplier." A forced multiplier (as I define it) is a way of circumventing innovation when it is discovered that innovation would decrease the wealth of those providing it. Forced multipliers can be found everywhere in our society today. They exist in the planned obsolescence of our phones and the disposable nature of consumerism at large. Forced multipliers are tremendously profitable in the short term but also do a tremendous amount of damage. The world we live in today doesn't simply provide innovation for the sake of innovation, it trades innovation for privacy, for information, for control, and to a lesser extent, a fee. This argument states that if there was a greater demand to cure cancer from a funding standpoint, we would have cured it. I think that is false. The ideal cure for cancer in the measure of profitability isn't a cure, it is treatment, a subscription. So this argument fails to point out the fundamental precursor for it to work: a social revolution, that is a shift from profit to purpose.

2. Spiritual Maturity: The definition of "what's better" is not a constant variable for all of humanity, nor should there be one "better" for all. It wrongly makes the assumption that everyone wants to live in a man-made dense urbanized, technology rich world as opposed to the idea of living more in tune and balance with the natural world. It seems to advocate that the newest idea is always the best one, which is not always true. We could stand to learn a lot from the way our ancestors used to live: -Climate control is an excellent argument here: when the luxury of forced heating and air condition didn't exist, our ancestors had to work with the land, environment and seasons to build their structures intelligently, even the color at which you painted something affected how it absorbed or reflected heat, our ancestors learned this. If we thought more that way today, we would not need as many resources and as much technology to circumvent the arrogant ways in which we build our homes and infrastructures today.

To the point of wealth equating to happiness, here is an interesting paradox: I know many people who have worked hard to amass a great deal of wealth only to end up on the other side of it in retirement unhappy and in "poor" health now spending most of that wealth on a treatment-based healthcare system that could have been avoided had they lived a different pursuit. This is largely because they sacrificed their well being in the pursuit of wealth, using coping mechanisms like over-eating, stress, over exertion and/or controlled substances to simulate the natural happiness that stems from being in the present moment. In contrast, I know people that have chosen happiness over wealth. They many not have a lot of money but they are in better health, therefore they are in less need of technology to right the problem in the first place. These people are not a drag on society nor are they billionaires, they have simply found balance. Where advancement constantly needs more advancements to correct the problems that the former advancements created, there is a spiritual maturity that is all too often overlooked in the idea of progress.

3. The Truth of Oneness: Your body is made up of 7,000,000,000,000,000,000,000,000,000 atoms, over 37 trillion cells and billions of sub-organisms that combine to form the person that you see in the screen from the selfie camera. If you break a bone, you don't view the atoms or cells in that bone as lazy or a drag on your otherwise perfectly working system, you view it as a result of a consequence that should be properly taken care of. Is your solution to a broken bone amputation? (or) Is it mending? What serves your body the best? Coming from this perspective it's easier to see how this same idea can apply to humanity as one even larger working organism. Not much of a jump then to see our planet the same way or our entire universe.

So the argument states that the industrial revolution created abundance for all but glosses over the fact that the industrial revolution would have never taken place if it hadn't first exploited the poor and working classes. This is a consequence of progress.

In the time of the industrial revolution, the abundance of nations like Europe and the US would have not sustained without the exploitation of other resource-rich nations who were often made to abandon their own cultures or even worse, whose own systems were made into often cruel puppet dictatorships allowed to persist as long as they freely traded with industrialized nations who touted "equality." This is an even bigger consequence of progress and in direct contradiction to the idea that "What helps the individual, helps the group."

We are a species who has become very accustomed to class-based systems. At first they were our means of survival. We selected our strong leaders because they would help our tribes grow. As our technologies advanced passed our own social maturity the idea of leadership became a distortion. We instinctively still feel we need it but it has become a formality that advocates ruling classes regardless of that class's qualification for leadership. In free market based societies, we like to pretend the the idea of an equal playing field exists even though it's fairly clear the playing field always favors those who were born into a certain level of privilege. The idea that financial wealth is and therefore should be the only means at which a person can uplift themselves overlooks the vast swath of those born into extremely hard circumstances with too many variables working against them. In other words, the broken bones, or the consequences of action.

For the prevailing wisdom of this argument to work, the idea of oneness has to be taken as a truth. What we do to others, WILL affect the whole absolutely and without exception.

Purpose following profit, Spiritual maturity, accepting Oneness: These are the foundations.

This is NOT altruistic at all, please don't say something so contradictory such as "egoistic altruism".
Altruism is the belief that your purpose in life is to live your life to serve other people, to put other people's interests above yours. Egoism is the belief that your own life and happiness is your moral duty, and that you should live for yourself.
The fact that it is in your self interest for other people to flourish, so you should make it a goal to make the world a better place, does not and should not mean that you should sacrifice yourself for other people.

This video speaks only from the perspective of innovation, but innovation requires, in addition to money available for investment, much R & D, time, and involves cultural issues. If all countries, as he says, were good life, he assumes that everyone will invest in innovation and the world will be a better place. But if everyone invests in innovation, following current consumption patterns, there will be a productive collapse as the focus of industries will change. By reducing production you reduce supply, and supply reduction leads to a rise in prices, pushing you back into the cycle of inequality in the long run.
If you look at a microeconomic vision, more money actually brings more innovation. However, in a macro view, even more involving all the countries of the planet with their due cultural differences, this is impossible. Just to see: until now, the biggest industry on the planet is the war industry. What is the chance for all countries to invest in innovations that improve the well being of the planet? What is the chance that extremely religious countries will start investing in space programs, for example?
This video is cute but this is extremely utopian. Everything that is proposed in it, besides being impossible to realize, would lead to inequality in long run.

..But the actual capitalist future world promoted in this video terrifies me.
After all, what if a purely-self-interested corporation decided artificial general intelligence would be a cheaper and more feasible way to achieve innovation than *literally eliminating world poverty*? (Whether or not it was) (Which could lead to them exploiting those artificial sentient beings (until governments make a massive slew of regulations, which will be obsolete by the time they're done), just as much as potentially it could lead to..well you know, making us need a reprogrammed Terminator X'D )

Are small corporations of hundreds of people focused only on one sector and the consequences relative to it, structured in a monarchy-like power structure, really an acceptable organizational structure to decide the existential fate of humanity for all seven billion of us? X"D

And as more and more of the salient commodities we create and consume are information, how will the zero-sum-ness and scarcity that capitalism and competition rely upon survive in such a positive-sum world...other than by even more and more egregious intellectual property law.

If an idea is what you make, how can you get money for it other than by controlling how it's used and shared? But to prevent the sharing and utilization of thoughts and ideas unless the collective has bequeathed you the authority to do so (whether by having lots of money in a capitalism or political standing in a marxism) is largely what made the Soviet Union and others so horrifying—thought policing!

Why can't we just let utopia naturally happen and restructure our civilization to accommodate freedom thought (that is, informational commodities), even if it means the most successful and motivated people in it will be Utilitarianists (people motivated by the good of all—including themselves but also others) and Passion-driven people (motivated by the love of what they do, rather than money), instead of Egoists (people motivated by the good of themself or "their own" (their "tribe/company/team/nation") without regard to the consequences upon others—good or bad) ?

This video makes the assumption that there is no limit to what we can do, but we don't know that. Planet Earth is limited in resources, it's a closed system which makes indefinite exponential growth impossible. Within our solar system surely, but beyond that, that might not even be possible. You should consider that there can be severe limitations in our primate brains that won't allow infinite growth, we're already having serious problems comprehending quantum physics, there could be a hard limit to our ability to comprehend our reality.

I kind of have a problem with your definition. What you would call altruism I would call investment.
An investment is egoistic, altruism is by definition not egoistic.
Let's take your cancer example. If you give money to a bunch of people to enable them to buy medicine you have less money to spend on medicine, you gave it to someone else. In the end the total amount of capital available to be spend on medicine stays the same. The only way giving money to others would increase the total amount would be if that money allowed them to get more productive. But as said such thing would be an investment not an act of altruism.

No. If I help others reach a standard of living where they're not tied to their needs but instead contribute to research, then yes, they'll improve life overall in the future. However if I spend 40 years of my life getting maybe 5,000 people well off, so that maybe 10 of them can then be researchers and possibly improve medicine to ideally cure whatever I may have died of in the future and extend my life by a small number of years until the disease they weren't able to cure gets me. I've been fairly favourable to this argument so far, but even then, 40>1-10, and any QOL improvements I get from these additional workers is minimal compared to the amount of time I'd lose enabling them.
If everyone were to help others by even a small amount and I merely contributed my part, it would be a totally different story. But that's not a selfish argument, that's a co-operative one. I simply receive greater personal benefit to myself by focusing my efforts on myself.

Long term this is the most sensible choice. The issue is that people on both extremes of the social ladder tend to think in short term.

After all, someone who has everything he could ever want and no worries, can do virtually anything he feels like it or simply find an alternative. While, in the extreme polar opposite, someone whose survival is a daily task, can't let up to think about fifty years from now, rather focusing on making to tomorrow.

Now, it doesn't mean they don't have long term goals. It's just that a billionaire can subside his wish for space travel via the many other ameneties he has access to and even simulation. While a beggar still needs warm clothing for winter but will trade it for food and water to survive a schorching summer.

Now, the issue becomes getting both of those, as well as the ones in the middle, to think about common ground. It's intrinsicaly hard, as natural selection and competition has created an extremely competitive race where those who let up get clobbered in the head. After all, common ground means trusting and cooperating with someone, that is risky.

Personally, I have little practical idea of how making that a reality within my own radius of influence. Much less how to reshape a global society and the species currently in control of it. My best guess would be the already mentioned issue of health and food. As well as knowledge, e.g. cientia (the word science is just knowledge and the fact that so many people use it without knowing is a very clear sign that it's not properly spread).

In many ways, we have reached the new height in those fields and it might seem pointless to push forward. Yet, the reality is that disease is still a big risk for everyone in this world and that culinary is still a prized field no matter the social degree, even though the requirements vary strongly. And knowledge of those fields are strongly dependent on others while it's still important to maintain the current one.

So, I imagine that we can find common goals in more than just curing cancer, that we could also agree in finding new tastes while preserving others. After all, medicine is an always evolving field, as we fight an arms race with a big plethora of ailments. While culinary is determined by ingredients, which can find and create or protect and destroy. And it's necessary to research other items to properly advance our knowledge of those.

Now, starting from the pressumption that we find such a common cause, we would need to first spread through our own community and range of influence. For it inherently depends on convincing from the inside of each group spreading the ideology to new ones, starting from the middle until reaching the extremes.

It's ironically similar to the spread of pathogens. Except that this would be a positive force for each person that comes in contact with it and starts spreading it further. That shows other issues, like the need to differentiate positive from negative strains of this base idea and how to better enforcing it.

In this case and from this perspective, it becomes very clearly more defined and finally taking the shape of something whose definitions are also full of secondary meanings: politics and religion.

Now, I also don't feel qualified to deeply think about it. But I would like to take a positive point from this, perhaps a silver lining. The idea that this crazy wish for a better world might be really hard to achieve and much easier to mess up. Yet, nonetheless, it's universal for all of us. And that the several stumbles and setbacks we have suffered and even self caused, were important steps in trying to achieve this goal.

Admitelly, it's a really positive optimistic take. But, when we are so deeply entrenched in pain or pleasure, I doubt it will be a chastising or a lecturing voice that will convince us more than the offer of a better place and a better feeling... The wish for a better world.
