If 7 billion people invest in a thing I want, I do not have any incentives to invest myself as I am going to get the thing anyway. Naturally, almost everyone starts doing that at some point, so the thing in question does not appear as quickly as it could. This is known as the tragedy of commons, and knowledge (in this case it might be a technology to produce the thing) is a common good, at least in part. So, it follows that only those who are genuinely willing to pay must have the knowledge. The governments in poorer countries are less likely to be interested in any technology apart from ways of money laundering. Then, it is not in the best interest of developed countries to give cheap or free resources to poorer countries. The argument only holds for investors who can earn a greater return on investment in underdeveloped countries, an ordinary taxpayer in many cases cannot be interested in sending his/her money abroad for the sake of 'humanity'. It is better for them when some new infrastructure is built in their place of residence.

However, this is a great video with extremely high quality graphics.

Except the reality is that the Earth only has so many resources, and "infinite growth" can't last forever. The problems with our market and momentary system is that people need to keep trading else the system collapses, it encourages greed and corruption, and increasing resource inefficiency(the opposite of economical).
It would be better to use the scientific method to develop a way to manage the "real economy" that puts humans first rather than arbitrary numbers. It would be more efficient to "share" things like transportation, rather then everyone have a car and only use it an average of 5% of a day. It would make more sense to get rid of all the unnecessary jobs that only exist to serve the system such as retail, banking, lawyers, etc, and focus on educating everyone so we can have magnitudes more scientists, engineers, and artists.
The human race has only spent a fraction of a percent of it's existence in our current paradigm, it would only serve our "human nature" and our prosperity to return to our egalitarian roots, and use our current level of technology to improve all our lives.

The best way to decrease the wealth gap? A massive increase in the supply of goods. Cheaper products = more valuable currency. The IMF and federal reserve have agreed that a little inflation is a good thing as it its scares consumers into buying now because the same product will cost more in the future. This 1-3% inflation rate creates an artificial demand. Besides the obvious negative affects of inflation, this has a negative affect on technology. Manufacturers aren't as motivated to find new and innovative ways to create cheaper products. Rather then save money, consumers buy immediately to the point of using debt to pay for everything. If this method of artificial demand existed in 1908, the mass production of the Ford model-T and the industrial revolution may have never existed. 65% of Americans save little or nothing and the average household debt is $139,000. The best way to achieve that "Global Pie" would be to make money redundant. Combine every country together and look after every human rather than just your country alone. Rather than companies needing to buy stuff with a budget, the materials are rationed out and supplied according to the necessity of the company's solution, while making sure they are either sustainable or will last long enough for a new source to emerge. The main thing holding us back is the existence of separate countries and the concept of trade being applied to everything.

The issue is that the world can still be a zero sum game in the short turn. For example, business executive could have a bigger pie in their lifetime if they don’t pay their employees properly and exploit a region for it resources. Altruism in the name of selfishness breaks down if the individual will not reap the reward of their investment of others because of the limiting factor of a human lifespan. Granted one could make the argument that their gifts could help the world at large after their death, but if we are strictly assuming the parameters of selfishness, selfish altruism can break down in the short term.

How does refrigeration increase supply and demand . . . ?

In fact it doesn't . . .
It decreases the need for more food because you can freeze food for months instead of letting it rot in days . . .
Insect populations decrease because they will not survive in a refrigerated environment . . .
the demand for insecticide goes down . . .

I'm sure you could go on and on with this list . . .
The point being supply and demand is just one facet of economy . . . but is not a true indicator of wealth or affluence
A more accurate picture would be . . . how well-off are the impoverished today versus one hundred years ago . . .
or how quickly can we accelerate their well-being . . .

this is sustainability and a better depiction of human endeavor . . .
It is also environmentally harmonious . . .

If you still have doubts you might try this . . .

You break a limb off of a tree . . .

A rudimentary form of technology . . .

While the argument in this video are supported by evidences, it is not an accurate model of how the world really is. Modern consumerism society is very much based on the idea of individual achievement, and achievement is subjectively defined. While some individuals can feel worth and proud by seeing the society as a whole doing better, many only care about individual gain in a strict sense. And even for those can take social progress as a part of personal achievement, some can stand some loss of personal interest, such as carbon tax will increase gas price(until you can afford an electric car), some can't stand personal loss. Perhaps in the very long run, indeed making others better off do make most people in another society better off, too, but change will always produce losers. The potential losers might very well be monopoly Establishment that has been very comfortable with secured power in hand. Human psychology react differently when there's power already in hand. It is like the one ring in LOTR, outsiders think it's just an object, but the holder of it don't feel that way( no matter who is holding). The real world is always messy, divided, unpredictable compare to ideal models. Blind belief in innovation's power is not the wisest thing to do. Models are models because they are over simplified.

Why does the video ignore the opportunity cost of investing in the development of less well-off countries? The same argument that says that a broader number of well-off people could invest more in cancer research also says that a limited number of well-off people could invest the same amount in cancer research if they weren't investing elsewhere with no change in the return. This is worth addressing because it's one of the greater practical problems with globalized development - its not in the immediate economic interest of people in already developed areas to pour money and resources into less developed areas on the promise of future payoff somewhere at some point down the line, especially since most of those who pay in (in the forms of taxes) are not going to see the pay out. Also, the video massively oversimplifies the complexity of technological innovation, particularly in medical fields since there's no direct correlation between the amount of money spent on, say, cancer research and actual progress towards a cure. This has been one of the major points of criticism towards cancer research in the West, which sees a lot of the resources granted for cancer research squandered on redundant testing because there's no unifying oversight of research, Making the Pie larger is GENERALLY better, but it takes much more than that to effect actual change, otherwise we'd have fixed the problems in Africa by now through just dumping money on the continent.

Agriculture is not a zero sum game.

Heard of a thing called the Dust Bowl? Hint: it's not a sporting event. Seasons, and their mildness, can also yield things called bumper crops. Look into a thing called winter wheat. Technology, such as tractors, harvesting & threshing machines, nitrogen replacement in the soil, selective breeding... all of these things increased crop output.

The status for thousands of years was not a war over territory. It was war over GOOD territory: cattle land & freshwater access. Cattle are your largest calorie-producing crop, and cooperative farming (you raise the feed, I raise the cows) was not a thing until Christian charity and contract law came along. The ranchers versus farmers war is as old as Caine & Able.

The big question is, "How do we bring that change about?" In the system that we are in, we are just a slightly more advanced version of the divide and conquer game. Instead of land, monetary assets are the name of the game. If those monetary assets are spread to those that have less, those that have more naturally lose in the exchange. There is a potential for monetary increase, but there is also a chance that little to nothing will be gained. It is a gamble, which the people must decide.
Do you wish to lose the luxury that you have today, for the possible outcome of a better tomorrow? I think that most people would rather live their lives happily, and ignore those that are worse off than them. People can be happy without all of the luxuries that they have, but people rarely choose to do so. It has to do with your frame of mind, and how you look at everything. Another point would be that it would take hard work, to bring it about. If people are living in a decent state, but would have to inconvenience themselves to make their situation better, the most likely outcome would be that they do nothing. I've learned of something called the 2nd law of thermodynamics and you can apply it on anything on this planet, and in life.
You can't get more money than you invest, unless that money comes from somewhere else outside your environment.
Now pumping money into 3rd world countries in order to help them get a better education sounds like a solid idea for innovation, but now keep in mind that in order for demand to exist, a depression of innovation must exist somewhere in order to direct the flow of money and ideas. Now you pump money into that area, and just like before a new demand for innovation emerges somewhere else. Now did anyone stop to take into account the changing standards of living? They say nowadays that if you go to the US with 10$ in your pocket and no debt then you are richer than half of all americans, yet in my own country that would make you poor, and while the economy and population of the world grows so does inflation. So while you might expect money to come your way due to demand in innovation, that money values less and less over time. 1 trillion dollars 50 years from now will be no different than 100 million dollars in the present,
I also find the idea with cancer treatment rather interesting, what would happen if 7 billion people afforded cancer treatment? ok, how do you do that? how do you make cancer treatment affordable to 7 billion people in order to get the money needed for innovation? because by the time you reach that state the treatment has become so refined and cheap that is requires no innovation, and maybe the inflation of the economy is so high that you can be poor while having millions of dollars in your bank account.
Also reality check, the resources of the planet are limited, do you actually believe that you can go on creating cake forever? there is a reason you need to you fertilizer, and if you use it then someone else isn't, and if you use insecticide to keep pest off your farm you are at the same time decimating the bee population, which I remind you is a serious problem. Is it any wonder that the bee population is at it's best in countries where farming is not so well developed?
Think of it like this: you give the farmer tons of free money, that farmer can afford insecticide, fertilizer etc and the yield of the farm will increase, but all the other farmers do the same. So while he produces more, the value of that work staus the same, yet the environment suffers, and their grandchildren will have to live by eating seafood because the death of bees will be the death of most life on Earth.
So yeah, you gain more pie, but the value of the pie decreases, if in the past 1kg of pie was 10$ then in the future 200 kgs of pie will be 10$, yet did anyone stop themselves to ask where the sugar, grain, fertilizer, water, etc came from? because it's not magical.

Todays accepted Socioeconomic system is a zero-sum game. To have winners, you must have losers.
We may use the argument of bettering the whole this way but in a dualistic universe (opposing forces in balance with each other), you cannot have more pleasure/progress/happiness in our system without having the negative aspect of these things created as a result.

We may deem it a positive sum depending on your moralities, but when you look at the success of the West and richer areas of the world, and then the correlated regression of poorer countries' labour conditions/resources/tax exploitation, it's easy to see that this is zero-sum. We use political systems as a veil and give the general public the illusion of any sort of power through "democracy", but this system is layered with ways of manipulating the interests of the powerful. The mediums of information (Media, clearnet, etc.) that reach the general public is heavily regulated by a small concentrated few that have incredible power.

The wealth gap is increasing, and human suffering in poor countries is worsening. It is an obvious pattern of zero-sum.

Egoistic Altruism is the only form of Altruism that exists. The baker doesn't bake bread in order to prevent others from starving, but because HE doesn't want to starve and he can bake well enough to sell his product to others.

Even if you do volunteer work, it's not purely altruism, because the person doing the volunteering gets something out of it - for instance, feeling good about themselves because they helped others in need. If there was no positive effect for helping others, no one would bother with volunteer work.

Therefore, altruism does not truly exist. Anything anyone does is done because there's a benefit to the person doing it.

What a healthy pattern of the electronic product was in three generations to achieve conception, reducing the cost, and finally increasing performance based on reduced-to-affordable prices that can support an ecosystem. As someone whose studied ancient civilizations. It is a bit of an oversimplification to say the ancient world was a zero sum game. This was true for territorial empires that relied on tribute, but from the perspective of the subsistence farmer, you were in a win-win relationship with anyone in your social/kin group, which could be small or universal depending on how you looked at it. Today we still think in terms of kin groups, but if you change how you think about it, this video is arguing that this includes everyone. For both modern and ancient cooperation makes sense based on your perspective.

Throwing my comment into the void here:
The success of the human race following the stated positive sum theory this video is predicated on, requires more people being wealthy enough to educate themselves and their children, leading to technological innovation, as well as a better understanding of the perils of past wastefulness.
It's not a repeat of the industrial revolution, but rather a sustainability revolution. It's in the best interest of the world and humanity to have sustainability in every aspect. Sustainable transportation technology, manufacturing, agriculture, health care, national and international political relations and practices, international non-partisan collaboration between innovators, and a system which allows people to pursue the innovations they come up with, while also regulating potentially harmful advancements such as biological warfare agents, destructive computer viruses etc.
Overpopulation is not an issue as long as innovation is being made in regards to cultural changes in how people are going to live, how much food we can grow, and how many people will be too busy educating themselves to have children. Wealthy countries tend to have a lower birth rate because there's no need to have 5+ children per household in order to survive, or have the children survive.
It's an ideal which is in almost every way utopian, which is why it should both be strived for, and closely monitored and scrutinized. It's easy to hide malicious inner working behind a pretty idea, but the idea is indeed pretty enough to be something we should all hope for the future.

And in case you're wondering about any of a mulitude of issues arising from the people we see being corrupt and wealthy today, the solution is simple: Through education of the masses, you lessen the gap between the obscenely wealthy and the non-wealthy, essentially giving the former fewer means of accruing more wealth, and less power over non-wealthy people. It's a race between those in power seeking to influence those below them, and those below them educating themselves in order to reduce the amount they can be influenced.

I find the arguments exposed in the video naive and in the end not really convincing. The idea of zero-sum game and positive sum game society seems kind of questionable. I know it is a concept from game theory, but is this something really used in economics or sociology? Anyway, here are some of my objections
1. It seems that you could argue that modern economy will eventually evolve to a zero sum game. The clearest reason being that resources on the planet are limited. We have temporarily been able to sustain economic growth building on the power harnessed from coal and oil, but this will not last forever. Even renewable resources are intrinsically limited in supply. So the "cake" will not keep growing forever, or at least not as fast as it did before. Most economists agree on this I think.
2. A lot is thrown under the carpet with the concept of "being better off" Do things like being part of a rich culture, having meaningful relationships with other people, etc ( immaterial things one can value in life) counts towards "being better off"? I think it should certainly be the case. Then preindustrial societies are far from zero-sum games and people in "underdeveloped" countries are not that poor. It seems that in these societies, there are even mechanism that diminish productivity in favour of immaterial goods (think about the prohibition of work on sundays for example).
3. It is explicitly said in the video that we tend to desire for more even when we get what we want. This is obviously enhanced in our modern societies. Why presuppose that we should just let this logic continue in an increasing way? Is it that crazy to be satisfied with what you have?
4. From an entirely selfish point of view, I want the indian worker’s salary to be as low as possible because any increase in his wage will be reflected on the price of my goods. It seems much more rational to stick to this logic rather than speculating about this guy’s children maybe going to college in 10 years, and maybe becoming scientists in 20 years and maybe finding the cure to cancer in 50 years.

I dunno, I think selflessness has always been beneficial to the self, even before the industrial revolution. Because if someone practices self-abnegation for the sake of others, if they help others survive, then they're valuable to the community The people around them are more likely to help them out in return, because they want to be able to continue to rely on that person. Like, I think communes can work IF they're necessary for survival, if there's no alternative. In that kind of situation, someone who does the work they're supposed to do and provides for the community is valuable; someone who's lazy and only takes from others isn't, and will probably be punished or ostracized from the community. After all, it's no coincidence that humans are such social animals; our interdependence on one another has been key to our survival and success. Of course, there are limits to this-- people do take advantage, and it probably only works that way on an inter-personal level. After all, humans generally think in terms of "us" and "them," because... Well, our time and our minds are limited, so we can't get achieve intimate knowledge of everyone we meet. It benefits us to surround ourselves with people we trust based on experience and knowledge, and to not trust new people so much. At least, that's true in a survival situation. But the easier life is, the less beneficial that instinct becomes. It's like how, in the stock market, if a stock crashes, it only becomes worse if everyone pulls their money out. Everyone knows this-- yet people don't trust each other to stay in. And when everyone else pulls out, the few who stay in really do lose the most; everyone wants to avoid that, so it becomes a self-fulfilling prophecy.

The market framing of innovation in this video is bad. All substantive technological progress came out of the non-market sector. R&D is a long-term and high-risk investment, and you cant afford such investing if you need to worry about being outcompeted. Take as one example Ma Bell, they invented transistors, modern cryptography, solar cells, the laser, the C programming language, and mobile phones; but when the monopoly was broken up, Bell Labs was sold off to Alcatel-Lucent, after a few years they announced they were cutting all funding for basic research to focus on more immediately profitable applications. The computer, mouse, Internet, digital camera, and email, radar, the jet engine, satellites, fiber optics, artificial limbs, nuclear energy, etc, etc, that all came from the state sector. Technological progress requires socialization of risk and investment.

Also, people can innovate simply bc its good for oneself and others to innovate. No one acts entirely selfishly, everyone thinks altruism is good. Basically everyone will agree that society should function with everyone's interests in mind, not only in the interest of a some subset of the populace. So, we should organize society so that innovation is invested in, and that everyone is well off.

Note that this doesnt even require radical change of the system, only a system something like the west already had between thirties and seventies. Although we are basically on the verge of automating the economy anyways, so some kind of radical change of the system will be necessary lol..

Developing the world to reach self-sustainability is a daunting task, something that is certainly not capable within our own lifetimes. Secondly, changing the world is nothing compared to changing the people. There will always be humans that wish to conserve their traditional ways, and will inevitably refuse modernization. Also, the 'Industrial Revolution' of the 19th century was invented by the Victorians to disparage the Middle Ages. The Industrial Revolution really began in the Middle Ages with inventions such as the heavy plow, horse collar, and crop rotation; as well as utilizing known technologies to greater extent, viz. windmills and watermills. The Romans didn't use windmills/watermills to great effect because it was cheaper to have slaves do the same work. When Medieval society gave up slavery on moral grounds, machines suddenly became the cheapest option and were thus adopted. These simple machines were developed over time to be more complex and effective. The 'Revolution' of the 19th century was simply a continuation of what started a millennium before.

The actual content of the video argues for a better well-being of the general populace, rather than egoistic altruism. The two are absolutely different, and this video is making a false equivalence of these ideas. But even if egoistic altruism SHOULD make you want to give to complete strangers half way around the world, the average well-being of the general populace is an inefficient way to progress compared to searching for good talent. What we need is concentrated effort - focusing resources on currently existing research programs, inventors, really smart people, or discovering promising people -- logically, they are the closest to the new breakthroughs and our best chance. It is far more likely that these people will lead to the cures for cancer and great inventions in the shortest time. Then, their inventions will make the world a better place.

Not only that, we already have many great ideas already. We do not lack ideas; we lack resources to test these ideas and execute them. The average well-being of the general populace will not lead to cures; you have to find talent, train them, and get them in research labs. If your goal is to be truly selfish, it doesn't make sense to help the entire world - only a small subset of it. Which is exactly why people who want cures for cancer will donate to certain organizations dedicated to this cause rather than giving aimlessly. Which is also why economists study how to best utilize resources and government funds because pouring more money doesn't always work and gives poor return on investment; it is difficult to make good use of money to make the world a better place.

What does this mean? Well, it means people who give a lot to complete strangers are truly good people. Giving is great, but not for the reasons stated in this video.

Kurzgesagt videos are usually very objective and thought through, even those containing somewhat controversial topics. This, unfortunately, is not one of those. While the idea of positive sum game society is a noble one and we as humanity should aim to build one, we are NOT in that state yet. To prove that I present you three fallacies contained in the video:

1, The exponential progress started by industrial revolution was caused by innovation. This is a half-truth. Yes, it was, but the cost of innovation itself was fueled by new, very cheap and to that point unprecedented energy sources, namely coal and oil. Growth of comlexity in the system is caused first and foremost by pumping more energy into it, clever reorganization comes only as a byproduct of this energy surge. Why? That leads me to number 2 -

2, Innovation does NOT come for free. This video treats innovation as some magical free resource, which is of course naive. Actually, the cost of innovation growths exponentially with time. In the past, you only needed one Isaac Newton to progress human knowledge a significant amount, these days, Nobel prizes are almost exclusively handed out to well funded teams, not individuals anymore, and discovering a single particle (say, Higgs boson) requires infrastructure and human resources comparable to Apollo project. And as all exponentials, this is unsustainable. It worked for a while, becouse the energy costs were hidden by mining cheap, milions of years built energy sources, but if we dont have something to replace them as they are depleted, expect, and let me quote Margin Call here: "the entire world get really fucking fair really fucking quickly". For an excellent resource on this topic search youtube for Collapse of Complex Societies by Dr. Joseph Tainter.

3, Finally, innovation in this video is treated as The Good Thing™, while this of course is again extremely simplified and misleading view. Internal combustion engines, nuclear weapons, Internet-wide surveilance, single use plastic containers or dragnet fishing are products of innovation the same way vaccines for cancer are. Why do you think Elon Musk spends his entire fortune trying to get people to space? He is just an IT guy who sees the whole picture and understands the importance of backups. Funnily enough, KurzGezagt has perfectly covered this topic in their own videos in the past.

There are some requirements for this that were disregarded in this video:
(The first sentence is the point, the rest is justification, and yes, there are things repeated because they are vastly intertwined.)
1. People will have to WANT to get the education. Right now, there are a great many people who have the opportunity to get the education they need, but because of cultural preferences, they consider education 'uncool' and don't pursue it. Until this changes, there will always be sections of the world, even within advanced societies, that will be poor. The brain is just like the rest of the body, and working it will make it stronger. Those who refuse to work it are not those who don't have the capacity. All people must be made to see this. If they want more, of they don't want to be poor, then they HAVE to work their own brains. Those who don't learn will be poor.
2. The investment must be done by those who both pay for it and reap the rewards. It can't be forced through government agencies who don't have to pay from their own pocket and take the rewards from those who pay for it. Excessive taxation and government spending do not advance anything, it only drags down the advancement. The reason this doesn't work is simple: those who don't invest their own resources have no interest in making it work the best way it can. Government workers aren't motivated to make things work properly, and most government projects will fail to get the desired effects. When people invest their own resources, risking the loss of it, they have a vested interest in making sure it is done right.
3. There will ALWAYS be some left behind. You're never going to change this. For people to move forward, they have to want to do so. Keeping them from feeling the results of their bad choices will just allow them to keep making those same bad choices. Allowing them to go without food or shelter for a time because they made the bad choice of spending their money on entertainment instead of expanding their self education will result in them making better choices later, and thus moving forward with society, and helping all of society to move forward even better and faster. However, at the same time, there are a lot of people who simply won't have the ability to find a place in the new world. There are some people who simply don't have the mental capacity to handle the complex tasks needed for a living wage. These people must be identified and cared for, but without including people who are just lazy. Government simply can't do that effectively.
4. Finally, there MUST be income inequality. It is an absolute MUST for such a world. It is a GOOD THING. Those who work harder and smarter make more. Those who refuse to work and push themselves forward will not get as much. That is the way it HAS to work. If those who refuse to work aren't penalized, then they have no motivation to change. If those who work hard and smart aren't rewarded, they will not continue, and others will not see what brings them rewards and won't do the things necessary to get there. Oh, and BTW, digging ditches, flipping burgers, sticking shelves, and hammering in nails is NOT working hard. It doesn't matter how tired you get physically. Working hard isn't working hard unless you are MENTALLY tired from it. Working you body means NOTHING. Working your BRAIN is what is needed. People need to be paid the value of their work, and flipping burgers is NOT worth anywhere close to $15/hour. Writing computer code is worth FAR MORE than flipping burgers. If you want more, get your nose in a book and LEARN to do more valuable work. That is the ONLY way this will work.

This argument is a bit flawed. There’s lots of finite resources—that everyone wants—which have no foreseeable replacements.
For example: land. If everyone is prosperous, then land-prices skyrocket. Nobody could buy lots of land. But if you’re rich, and others are poor, you can buy much more land for far less cash. Then you can charge poor people rent and get even richer.
Innovation might help solve this issue a little. For example, humans can colonize other planets, or create virtual land that feels real. But Martian and virtual real estate isn’t about to replace Earth land anytime soon. Even if Martian land was attainable right now, most people would still choose 100 Earth acres over 1000 Martian acres. And even if virtual land feels 100% real, you still can’t use it to grow real crops, for example.
In other words, some finite resources have no comparable replacements in sight. And in this regard, it’s good to be super rich and let others stay poor.

There’s one important caveat to note. If wages increase exactly as much as prices increase, the purchasing power of those wages will stay the same. Many employers have a standard practice of increasing wages along with inflation, and in that case the wealth effect won’t come into play. But the same can’t be said for wealth that you have stored as cash in your wallet, in non-interest-bearing chequing accounts, and in other dollar-denominated assets that won’t necessarily increase along with inflation. Even when wages keep pace with increasing price levels, most people will probably still experience some reduction in real wealth, causing consumption to fall.

For those of you who may be struggling to understand the concept, you can apply the same general principle on a much smaller scale and it works out the same. A simple example is a close friendship: You support your friend and in turn they support you. In the end, you both gain from supporting each other.

That's it. Seriously. You apply that concept on a broader scale (which is more or less what this video is doing) and the logic doesn't really change. It's a simple principle of cooperation at its core. It's one of the core things underpinning the success of our species. The main obstacle is indoctrination, throughout human history, that pits one "tribe" of human beings against another. Meaning, cooperation happens within the tribe, but not in support of "the other" tribes.

This video helps put it in perspective, free of tribalistic mentalities, that you are better off with the human species cooperating (rather than segmenting into warring tribes), no matter how large scale it becomes.

You see, innovations, especially as more advanced they get, require more and more capital and expertise to utilize as well as develop. (to use your examples of shoes and planes, it takes much larger engineering expertise as well as capital investment to create planes than shoes.) This means that the fruits of the innovations are being less and less equally available, and less and less of the 'pie' is being shared for everyone else. Think about it. If you take cell phones for example, the market is being more and more monopolized, all you see is apple and samsung. This also means that resources (often natural resources, such as metals, oil and such) produce more utility in the hands of ones that monopolize innovations. The result is that innovations, while increasing the total product, ironically takes away resources from the 'less innovated'. This is exactly what is happening in many 'third world' countries, where the developed nations with their powerful, more advanced industries exploit the natural resources while contributing little to the local economy and its development.

Positive-sum human interactions didn't begin with the industrial revolution, they go all the way back to the most rudimentary examples of exchange and specialization in proto-human history--and the fact that we evolved the capacity for positive-sum interactions is the most important factor in the success of the human species. We were the first species to be able to "trade" (rather than "share" or "gift," to exchange resources with the expectation of receiving something in return whether in the future or immediately). It started with the evolution of gender roles, where females became specialized in caring for children and foraging for edible plants or small animals nearer to camp while males became specialized in hunting larger prey further from camp, allowing both sexes to benefit from each other's specialized work, and allowing the tribal unit to benefit from the work of individuals.

Progress was very, very slow for the majority of human history, but exchange between humans has always been positive sum to the extent that it has been voluntary--if one of us is willingly exchanging something with another, whether in a momentary trade or a prolonged social arrangement, it's because each person subjectively values what they are receiving more than what they are giving up, and that's positive-sum by definition. The reason it took so long to reach the point where the "economic pie" was growing at the speed we see in modernity was not because we were merely waiting for the technology that enabled the industrial revolution, it was because we were waiting for the cultural and political changes birthed from the European Enlightenment which slowly led to an institutional recognition of property rights for people outside of the nobility (along with a growing emphasis on consent in governance). The broadening institutional recognition of property rights meant that for the first time, common people could become merchants or skilled tradesmen and accumulate wealth for themselves, instead of for lords or guilds; for the first time, common people could save for the future with some assurance that their savings would not be outright confiscated by the ruling class, allowing generational wealth accumulation and enabling investment in the enterprises of others. Culture began to shift from one that denigrated merchants and businesspeople to one that tolerated them. Voluntary exchange and association became a much greater part of the social order and public life, drawing a great many more human minds into the productive economy and enabling them to benefit personally when they applied their creativity to discovering valuable new ways of solving problems for others. These changes preceded and produced the technological innovations that drove the industrial revolution.

Technological progress and economic growth, fundamentally, are the effects of a growing proportion of voluntary human exchange and interaction as opposed to coercive human exchange and interaction, and this continuum tracks back throughout the entirety of human history. Individual consent is the fundamental virtue underpinning all human progress, and it only took a relatively limited expansion of respect for individual consent in a few particular areas to create the explosive growth in technological advancement, wealth generation, and social progress that we have witnessed since the industrial revolution. The "human family" can progress as fast as we want, in every sense of the word, if we focus on broadening and deepening the importance of individual consent throughout our political and cultural institutions.

The positive-sum game works once you can get an economy to start thinking beyond subsistence-level farming. You get beyond subsistence-level farming by using farming techniques and inventions to multiply the output of farmers well beyond that subsistence-level. And you can only create farms that large and stable today if you can guarantee the farms and farmers the peace needed to maintain them.

In areas which disrupt that peace, typically through the use of ideas of those farmers having more food than they know what to do with and not sharing "fairly" with everyone around them, the farmers cannot create this basic fundamental bedrock on which a positive-sum society is formed. See what happened in Zimbabwe, or what's happening in South Africa, or what's happening in Venezuela (although the seizure there is principally from manufacturers, not farmers, but the effect is identical.)

There is no positive-sum society in socialism. By nature of socialism itself, the best possible case for society is zero-sum... and most of the time, it can't even accomplish that.

Nope. As much as I respect Kurzgesagt and enjoy the videos, this one is based on a false premise and spirals to la-la Land.
All species on Earth optimize their survival through energy usage within some ecological context. There are limiting factors that regulate the growth of all species. As energy moves through an ecosystem, individuals gain some of that energy for metabolism, growth and reproduction by short circuiting entropy. They do this in ways particular to their species and within their ecological niche. In time and with stable conditions ecologies can stabilize and even diversify, creating more opportunities to transfer the flow of energy through a widening entropic network. That is what life on does and what humans did until relatively recently.
Today our culture increases its share of energy by replacing biological diversity with monoculture. We replace millions of years of energy optimization with techniques that benefit only ourselves and a few microbes. Solargy budgets are subsidized by fossil fuels and geothermal and nuclear. What our culture does is to short circuit entropy at a massive scale, leaving a wake of death destruction and extinctions.
We're clever, so far by substituting limiting factors, but each of these replacements brings a new set of limitations, and unintended consequences.

This is a weird video. You're using the rhetoric of capitalism to essentially make an argument for post-scarcity communism. I can't tell if that was intentional or not. It's interesting because it feels like techno-utopians are so interested in progress that they're willing to throw out capitalism if it's holding us back, but they lack the language to articulate that in a comprehensive way, so they fall back on neoliberal rhetoric. This is kind of like Universal Basic Income in that way. It flies in the face of capitalist ideals, but people will use capitalist rhetoric to make arguments for it.

Anyway, I'm completely down with the ideas of continuing progress, but this video glossed over some major political problems our current society faces in getting there. For instance, the pie is indeed bigger, but the inequalities are still there. How could the positive sum game be applied to labor relations (Employer-Employee relationship)?

Unfortunately Kurzgesagt have gotten it backwards. There has always been a positive sum game, but it is counterintuitive to us. The early economic understanding was that all things had an intrinsic value, which was fixed and metaphysical. So in their understanding, all trade was a system of a winner and a loser. That is the zero sum game, and it was never the actual state, it was just a part of some outdated economic systems like mercantilism (nationalist), socialist and Marxist economies.

Secondly, altruism was the dominating system during the medieval period. The Church owned a third of all land, and provided for the poor. Education, work, welfare, retirement etc. a little problem of course was that it kept people poor for generations. The Church also kept altruism a dominance in the state. Again that is something intuitive to us, take care of people, we don't like to see people suffering. Socialism doesn't need trying out, it was the dominating economical system for the entire medieval period, it is the feudal system.

Now comes the 19th century, they learn that there is a positive sum game, which is unfortunately not the stab of death to mercantilism. It should be, but the zero sum game is just too intuitive to us, that it keeps coming back in different forms. There is an age of laissez-faire economy, free trade and growing peace and prosperity for all. One of the great maxims, altruism, is challenged, because self-interest is better at serving our fellow man than altruism. Also the free market does a better job at regulating itself than governments are, the economical crises since of the 20th and 21st centuries were caused by government meddling. These are the lessons Adam Smith, which lead to the progress of the 19th century.

In short, what is intuitive to humans, is what works in small communities. Altruism is fine in a small community, it's how our ancestors survived, but it is destructive to the state. If we take the central lesson from this video to heart, it is "the quicker we progress the better it is for mankind". And that road is paved with self-interest, not altruism. But the lesson is also clear, the reverse, that egotism is what helps the most people in the world - altruistic egotism. By spending your money, you are helping people all over the world.

It seems like there are some areas where this "bigger pie" analogy might not fit. Natural resources for one. The most immediately obvious is coal and oil, but a cursory search suggests that there are plenty of other resources that will still be in demand if/when we unshackle ourselves from those non-renewables: lithium, phosphorous, medical isotopes, helium. Hell, one could make an argument for fresh water and carbon credit emissions.

The ecological footprint of the US citizen is 4-ish. For Norwegians it's a bit under 3. This implies to me it is not currently sustainable to get everybody living to the same standards at the first world without requiring a few more worlds.

So what are we relying on to do this? Your nominal 'innovation'. If we raise everybody to a first world standard of living we're now in a race to make sufficient technological breaks to reduce the global footprint while still maintaining living standards before we run out of planet and end up in some sort of Malthusian collapse.

So a statement like 'the more people who want the same thing you want, the more likely you are to get it', in the context of the above, seems dangerously glib. You might be right. And you might be wrong.

For the record I strongly believe that what is propose (enriching and improving the standards of living of those in the second and third world) is ethically the right thing to do. But I am not convinced it is also in my personal self interest, because I am objective enough to look at this without the bias of cognitive dissonance.

I am literally typing this while on holiday in Asia, where I am living like a (modest) King for fairly cheap. Why? Again, I don't delude myself: because I am comparatively wealthy here. Bringing these people up to my standard of living - the benefit that will be realised from this will not be seen for a generation, maybe several. In the meantime their relative indigence provides immediate material benefits to me, as they shell my seafood, assemble my iphones and sew my shirts.

Do not delude yourself: first world living standards are sustained through the blood, sweat and tears of the poor.

Selfishness only makes the world a better place in extremely specific circumstances. If you set up a normal-sounding dilemma where selfish-identifying people have to make a choice between doing something empathetic whose only benefit is helping others, and doing something cruel whose benefits include more power, the majority of those selfish-identifying people would choose to be cruel. You don't want to set up a situation where everyone behaves the way selfish-identifying people do. People who identify as egoistic altruists would be inclined to say they only do nice things because it personally benefits them, and as soon as it does not, then they will be cruel. You do not want to set up a situation where everyone behaves the way that egoistic altruist-identifying people behave.

As i see it, there are three different ways that could achieve a higher standard of living for people in developing countries:

1. A brilliant idea. Finding an incentive for firms and housholds to invest into the economy of these countries which leads to a higher wealth for the domestic population, resulting in a higher demand for a solution of first world problems.

2. Political redistribution. First world countries vote for left wing parties who redistribute the wealth of industrial countries to developing ones.

3. Time. Economic growth happens also in poor countries, but in a much slower pace. Based on the Solow Growth Model we will reach a steady state eventually and can only increase output if we raise our human capital or physical stock (e.g. investing the education of citizens from poor countries).

I think there's a big problem with the argument if you add to the problem natural resources endowments because then the game remains a zero-sum game. This approach has been studied by the ecological economy. There is a fundamental difference between countries or regions that exports natural resources and agricultural production and those that produce knowledge-intensive and industrial goods that are work intensive. That difference creates incentives for the developing world to keep natural resources, including energy sources of course,  cheap, flowing to their regions and out of the underdeveloped ones. Those incentives are not handled throw the market, supply and demand, but in the international, (or inter-regional) political arena. Taking in to account only market mechanisms and keeping natural resources out of the equation gives a distorted understanding of the problem.

So the core idea behind the video is that thanks to innovation, the world's economy is a plus-sum game, and that allows increasing living standards for all. There is certainly a kernel of truth to that assessment, but the video fails to address several problems.

1. While the entirety of consumer products is a plus-sum game thanks to innovation, the entirety of natural resources that are needed to produce these products (materials, land, freshwater etc) are are not. Control over these finite natural resources means control of the world's economy. Thus the fighting and extreme economic inequality never stopped, it just largely shifted away from our cosy industrial "winner" countries.

2. The video entirely ignores one crucial ingredient to both the industrial revolution and our global economy today: cheap labour. As is, a global economic utopia where all 7 billion people are well-educated and wealthy and free to innovate can't exist, the cost of labour would make prices of goods rise to the point were some people can no longer afford good education and are no longer wealthy and free to innovate. Our current system at our current level of technology requires some people to be economically desperate enough to do the work that no one wants to do. Of course, automation (innovation) does have the potential to solve this problem, which brings us to our next problem:

3. Capitalism. Yes, if it wasn't political already, this is where politics becomes unavoidable. In a perfect world, the abolishment of human physical labour due to automation would benefit everyone. but in a capitalist world, it only benefits the owners of the finite natural resources as described in point 1. Resourceless people who so far needed to undersell their labour in order to survive can now no longer even do that, since there is no way they can compete with automation once a certain level of innovation is reached. And of course, without the assets, they are also barred from the level of education required for them to live off "innovating".

In conclusion, if we continue on this path, the plus-sum nature of potential consumer products will become irrelevant and we will end up back in the zero-sum game of natural resources, with even worse options for poor people than in the thousands of years before.

This argument doesn’t depend on an economic system or political system. It simply make the claim that if more people are educated and wealthy, the drive for innovation increases, as it increases the supply of innovators and the demand for innovation, and in turn makes everyone’s lives better. This is all the video claims.

In my opinion, If all wealth creation is held in the hands of the few, than this won’t lead to a better world, as a thousand dollars spent of educating a college student will not yield the same net gain as a thousand spent on an illiterate. So we need a system that encourages open innovation and plurality as well as a just distribution of wealth. So not capitalism, as it results in the hoarding of wealth and power, leading to authoritarianism, and not state socialism, as it has a tendency to abuse its authority, but rather something like mutualism or municipalism. But that’s my opinion. If you think that another system is better at reaching the goals stated in the video, then there you go.

How do you think we got to the industrial revolution in the first place? It sure as shit wasn't the product of zero-sum economies and stagnation.

Kurzgesagt, I appreciate your take on this, and even if I disagree on some of it, I still can see where you're coming from, and think the professional presentation of your ideas is very polished, and thought through. I do want to state, however, that it sometimes feels like you're trying to tell people that your way to our success is simply the best way to gain success in this world, and personally, almost sounding like other ways are flawed because not everyone can be happy by those ideals. This, to me, sometimes almost comes across as a small bashing of people who choose to fight for their lives in self-inclosed ways, instead of by helping others, equally to helping themselves.

In fact, the only thing I found egotistic about this video (while not the biggest cardinal sin in the book) was your belief that everyone, like you, would want to help the world to become a better place. While I and many others do believe the world can always be better, there are just as many people out in this world who are content staying in their bubbled zero-sum communities, which is absolutely fine. It's hard enough finding purpose in life originally, let alone asking people to fight for yours without physical evidence they can pull from their lives to support your, albeit, very well thought out, perspective.

My simple fear, in taking this to the extreme, is that your perspective will be forced on others for "the betterment of humanity," instead of agreed upon and implemented until we find the next best way to support humanity, or, if this actually does succeed, until greedy people across the world choose, in this new zero-sum world, to start taking pieces of the pie again, and start this process over.

We’re still in a zero-sum game. The resources are still finite, though technology has transitioned the nature of what’s being exchanged. We now trade time, instead of resources. Our wages are based on a principle of debt for a good or service being produced, and the time we sacrifice for that. Some people’s time is worth drastically more than others’, and as technology and innovation go further and further, you’ll continually see that very wealthy individuals will compile more and more of this “pie” of value.

Your time is not even valuable unless if you exchange it with a company for wages, as almost all resources are claimed, privately owned by important and wealthy people. You can invest in the value of your own time by setting yourself up to farm, or to produce content, but you’ll be forced to heavily rely on companies for your only valuable resource (time) to be exchanged.

These days, instead of survival, you’ll slave your life away to pay off debts that seem contrived and forced upon you, sacrificing years upon years for the hope of enjoying retirement when it’s all over, never being allowed to live while still young.

I think the theory behind most of the video is good, but the parts about innovation being driven by supply and demand are a bit... wrong? Maybe that's a bit harsh.

Beyond the fact that lifting people out of poverty is a good thing and the more people that are able to work on technology the better, there is little evidence that monetary incentive actually helps technology advance. For instance, all the components on the original iPhone were developed in the public sector. As Muzzocato says in her book The Entrepreneurial State “Every major technological change in recent years traces most of its funding back to the state”. In addition, we can see that inventors are almost never compensated for their efforts. You can't just say "the demand for innovation increases as people get richer and can pay for new solutions" because the profit motive doesn't make people "invent harder".

This whole video is also a bit of a bad faith argument. Shouldn't we just be helping other people because it's morally right? What we really want isn't for other people to think that helping others benefits themselves, but that helping others is morally right and an intrinsically good thing to do.

Lastly, if you accept that you will be better off if everyone else is better off, then you have to recognise that this conflicts with capitalism. The system of motivations capitalism provides incentivizes precisely the conditions we see today: The systematic exploitation of weaker and poorer countries. While it would be great for everyone if these people were treated like human beings, the people in charge of extracting money from them benefit more from withholding this from us. If you care about the future of humanity, you can't just sit by and let the world be held to ransom by a handful of corporations when we have the resources and technology to resolve our problems if we just worked together with the goal of alleviating suffering rather than maximizing profit.

Kurzgeasgt is right at an aggregate (total) level. But there is plenty to discuss on 'creative destruction' and how it is actively attacking and being attacked by vested interests. The other criticism is that there is a lot of heterogeneity in the world and that at some point you can reach diseconomies of scale - there are limits to what people with different understandings can come to cooperate on one single thing. Then there's the risks in academia of creating path-dependencies where fringe ideas are less tested because the consensus is against them. Finally, there's all the frictions that make such transfers of wealth and knowledge very slow. As a comment I have seen previously argued, the organisations with the capabilities of empowering wealth distribution are short-sighted and would rather focus on extracting a greater part of the pie than of growing it. Other frictions include behavioural ones - Kahneman and Tversky having listed our biases and heuristics which are the barriers for good ideas to come to fruition.

As an ideal and an eternal reminder, yes - everyone's gonna benefit if everyone is better off. But taking it at individual levels, some people will still lose. I honestly just want there to be fairness in that competition, because overall-losers still win plenty of times.
I think everyone can agree that the world would be better if everyone was prospering, but the question is, how do we get there?

But isn't it the fact that relatively poorer countries better facilitate cheap labor  the reason complex products can be made affordable to enough to keep said products in demand? Great idea... shame it doesn't really work in capitalism and consumerism. We need a fundamental paradigm shift in order to make this "growth" sustainable. While the industrial revolution gave us better and easier access to resources, it didn't create more resources, let alone infinite resources as the makers of this video seem to suggest. The agricultural revolution has provided a burst of growth, but we've depleted the minerals of our soils. In order to fix that, we've added fertilisers which have in turn messed with the Nitrogen and Phosphor cycles of our environment, which has, in turn, caused nutrification in our rivers and oceans, which is, in turn, driving toxic algal blooms akin to the one seen in Florida a couple of years ago... A core premise seems to be that the aggregation of prosperity is an indisputably far-reaching factor in increasing innovation.

While it is indisputable that the concentration of capital, something symptomatic of material prosperity, affords higher risk-taking and simple investment, it is not very clear how these things actually influence innovation, an act which by its nature seems something profoundly individual, creative, and not altogether moved by anything in the aggregate, be it people or their conditions.

I think it is probably more accurate to just identify how entrepreneurial activity and innovation serve as productive catalysts in a division of labor economy, where the augmentation - not the aggregation - of labor is what counts. So it's not simply that industrial society affords innovation, but that innovation affords its recognition more powerfully in an industrial setting.

If we presuppose some functional relation (exponential even, if you'd like) between material prosperity and innovation, then innovative opportunities in more advanced industrial settings are at once more potent than the ones whose costs are being payed for by those aforementioned settings, i.e. the less affluent. Thus, in appropriating funds for those costs, in virtue of that very act, the unseen (a la Hazlitt) necessarily takes on a value higher than the seen prosperity affected by the stolen funds. Even if you want to invoke some sort of horizontal appropriation, i.e. funding across different industries (as though innovation in each industry were constant with one another!) as opposed to down through different levels of industrial capability/affluence (this would be "vertical") you still lose out on the time-costs of enacting those appropriations.

This is one of the dumber video this channel has produced. It gets just about everything wrong: from its insane, arbitrary definitions of "zero sum game" and "positive sum game" to its misappropriation of supply and demand, all the way to its apparent thesis that total wealth continues to magically increase in a post-industrialized world. Wealth is not a social construct, it is an indicator of economic utility. Economic utility is the capacity of a resource to satisfy a human (or "society" in macro-economics) want.

You simply can't ignore resource production in any macro-economy. Even if you live in a society that has largely evolved its own economy past the point of needing a large population of manufacturers, that does not mean your economy doesn't rely on manufacturing. It just means that your society is able, at a sustainable rate, to trade for the requisite manufactured goods from another society. Right? This is how trade works-- it allows some societies to specialize and, as consequence, spreads access to goods and services to a much wider domain. However it does not negate the necessity of manufacturing-- it just concentrates where it comes from. We cannot live in a macro, global economy that is mostly (or entirely- as this video suggests) made up of information/ service sector micro-economies. Resources matter!

Example: Just because I did not harvest the cotton my clothes are made from does not mean that cotton isn't a valuable resource to me. I didn't chop down the trees that provided wood for my chair or desk, nor did I mine the gold that's in the motherboard of this computer. But someone did, thus allowing this Internet video to waste seven minutes of my life. Had there been no society whose economy manufactured these resources, none of this would even be possible.

Technological advancement does not negate this principle. Tech production and tech progression still need resources. Production of ANYTHING will still need a supply of resources-- i.e. magic does not exist in the real world.

I would like condemn this video for poor fact checking or lack of healthy pre-production criticism but I suspect that the actual roots for this video's anti-intellectualism are more nefarious. So to address the ugly, black-masked elephant in the room here, socialism is a bad idea because it is built from failed ideas. It has never worked. It will never work.

I like how this video was funded by the Bill Gates Foundation when he's part of the reason we're still in a world where some people get more "pie" than others. For example: The Gates Foundation uses its immense wealth to advance libertarian-y causes like the privatization of public schools. Even when its fund benefits traditional public schools, it de-democratizes things like curriculum. Common Core, for example, was broadly pushed by the Gates Foundation and tied to basic funding promises.

Also, a lot of people in here are very confused about capitalism vs "socialism" aka libertarian socialism. Capitalism is when the means of production is owned by business owners and corporations ect. Socialism is when the means of production is owned by the people, the working class. The video is cannot be arguing in favor of capitalism because in a capitalistic society, people HAVE to be poor for others to be rich. Corporations must benefit from the work and products/services produced by its employees and so forth. Some people have to have more cake than others.

This video is saying that's bad and that everyone should get an equal portion of cake. In this scenario, the means of production would have to be owned by a people as a collective so that no one would be able to dominate the cake and take a majority of it. JUST BECAUSE THERE ARE GOODS THAT ARE PURCHASED WITH MONEY WITHIN A MARKET DOESN'T MAKE A SOCIETY CAPITALISTIC. The altruism displayed in the video is encouraged in this type of society because it would mean everyone would be able to have access to things like food, healthcare, even luxuries to some extent.

Eventually, the currency system would probably be abolished anyway if this system continued because there would be no need for money if everyone pitched in and everyone was "rich". The concept of money really is a way to enforce the powers of capitalistic business giants and keep them powerful for as long as the system allows them to. So, in a way, the values expressed in this video could be interpreted as leftist anarchist, although that's not explicitly what it says so I don't think it's safe to interpret it like that, especially with Bill Gates funding it.

It's a great idea, except that there's really only ever been one big pie, which consists of all the natural resources in the world.
If there's 7x as many consumers then natural resources are consumed at 7x the pace.
And ultimately everything we produce eventually becomes garbage (almost nothing is infinitely recyclable) so we're simply converting natural resources into garbage at 7x the pace. This is a positive sum game.
Jevons paradox illustrates that whenever we attempt to become more efficient (usually with the stated goal of consuming less natural resources), exactly the opposite occurs. We simply become more efficient at converting natural resources into garbage at an ever increasing rate. e.g. Adding insulation to your business's building, saves energy, saving you money, which you reinvest in the business, to produce more widgets (consuming more natural resources). Or.. buying a more fuel efficient car, allows you to live further from the expensive urban area, where on the same salary you can afford to buy a much bigger house (consuming more natural resources).

The world was only a zero sum game until the dawn of agriculture. Before then, the amount of food you could produce was roughly the same as you consumed. The amount of value you could create (value = a need or want) was roughly the same amount of value you consumed. Food was only gathered or hunted, and land had a set amount of food that replenished over a certain amount of time, so migration was necessary as the population increased.

Then agriculture was developed. This made it so that one person could produce enough food for 11 people. This resulted in 10/11 people being able to do things other than create food. They created other forms of value, like housing, or clothes. Farming also created slavery and animal husbandry - one person could grow enough food to support 10 other humans, or other animals, and thus slaves then became profitable - before agriculture, slaves were mostly impossible to keep, as you couldn't feed them.

I disagree with this video on land usage and agriculture - the world wasn't a zero sum game during times of agriculture, and there wasn't a shortage of land until very recently - 1,000 years ago. Very blatantly wrong.

Innovations kept being created, one of which was better agricultural practices, which made the 1 person able to farm enough food for 32 people, instead of 11. This further increased the amount of people able to do things other than farming. This number kept increasing. Agriculture is the direct cause of laws, civilizations, war, slavery, etc. Also the cause of all technology and modern pleasure.

Because of the innovations of agriculture, new innovations in other fields were made. With every innovation, the amount of value a person could create increased. The reason life is so awesome now is because every person can create more value then they consume. 1 person can create enough value for 10 people to be satisfied easily. Value is defined as something that gives someone pleasure. Food and other basic needs give pleasure, but so do things like gold, video games, TV, clothes, etc. With the creation of industry, one person can create enough value to satisfy thousands of people.

Okay... It's a good ideal and bears merit overall...
This is a gross oversimplification, however. I know "for nothing more than a YouTube video" it's a principle that needs simplified to some extent, and that's also certainly worth merit... BUT the most notorious misrepresentation here is "...that we've been making a bigger pie..."
Folks, it's a planet. It hasn't been getting THAT much bigger (cosmic dust and hair-splitting aside) in the last couple thousand years (or probably several million)... If you don't get off-world and find more pie to bring physically back here, the pie does NOT get any bigger.
SO what have we done? We have advanced technology and explored more of the pie we have to BE ABLE to use it more efficiently. Certainly, this is still important, probably more important than anything to do with making a pie any bigger... BUT it has NOT spontaneously generated a "Positive sum game" from a "Zero sum game"... Society did that as an invention WAY BACK around the time we (humans) invented things like farming and livestock... and villages.

Frankly, I'd suggest investing just a little time to check out the work of George R. Price... Particularly his efforts in applying game theory to natural selection. THAT will explain quite effectively how "selfless activity" (altruism) is in fact the positive efforts of your own genes seeking to influence their own preservation through socialized effort.
This is simple. It's no more than cooperating within the society to efforts for the net benefit of others, which in turn creates a social trait of reputation... That reputation creates an additive trait of VALUE in your person for others, and thus they ACTIVELY seek to keep you around. Now, this is also a simplification. It's the narrowest scope of the simplest model of the theory. BUT it proves the point without any neo-mystical ideologies of "generating bigger pies" out of thin air, something that is basically impossible.
This same notion works in greater scopes from individuals in groups, to smaller groups within larger social structures, and from larger structures showing their support of even "offensive" neighboring structures when in need... Needs get met, and people are happy. Reputations grow and values increase... Neighbors appreciate GOOD neighbors, and seek to keep them around. The cycle of investment to returns (not always monetary) can and WILL always function well mathematically...
Finally, I'd like to point out that George Price's work has the dubiously extraordinary feat of not containing citation outside of his own work. This is something that was even held as extraordinary in the early 1800's, and is all the more impressive when you understand he was still publishing papers on these and related matters into the 1970's...

I don't disagree with Kurzgesagt. I actually enjoy their work, and I find it (mostly) useful, relevant, and beneficial. I just honestly, truly think this could have (should have?) been done from a less fantastical perspective and the references to Price and others involved in the likes of applied game theory could give viewers something to take note and research heartily on their own... I can understand seeking to influence a younger viewer base, but fantasies of bigger pies instead of the hard reality of more efficiently enjoying all the pie we have leads too easily to fallacy... and innovation for the sake of change is NOT innovation for the sake of pay-off... pay-off should be celebrated. (that's where you get closer to the cure for cancer) ;o)

Repeatedly increasing the size of the pie is not the same thing as an infinite one. The world is still zero sum...just a bit less. There is a reason every country on Earth is not flooded with an oversupply of rare-elements and expensive machines and other rare/ expensive things. There are only so much of them. For any resource or service, no matter how much you increase it, there will always be a finite amount. Example: there are only so many doctors to provide healthcare. There are only so many farmers to grow food, only so many soldiers to defend you. Putting people in one economic sector usually means they are not in other ones, so no matter how much investment of resources you put in it will never be a positive return for all areas. Now make no mistake, I see few flaws in the video apart from this. Increasing the number of people who are able to produce and innovate will absolutely benefit you in the long term. But you must spend resources to produce resources. Not every part of the world, individual person, or section of the economy has an efficient ratio. Many are even net losses.
The only other thing that comes to mind is something else it said: basically as you solve problems you develop new ones to solve. Apply that to resources (objects, time, services, etc). No matter how many resources you consume, you will always have a demand for new and different ones. Meaning your consumption keeps increasing to counter your new wealth. It gets more and more and more expensive to keep you alive even as innovation drives that cost down.
It is definitely in your best interests to help people. But here is the better question: Is it practical or realistic?

Actually, we all have cancer. It's a mutation in a cell that causes uncontrollable division, etc, that the body is normally able to suppress on it's own. It's when the body's built in defenses and the cells' own failsafes stop working that tumors develop. Cancer has thousands of potential variations depending on the location and the mutations causing it. So there is no way to prevent it, only treat it. We can only get better at identifying the mutations causing it, and targeting the cells carrying those mutations.

This is a great argument for a collective mentality we should have, and makes common sense, but the reason why we aren't living like this is because this mentality doesn't factor in one thing: The more that an individual is able to contribute to these sorts of investments, the less likely it is that they are to benefit directly from such investments. Why would a rich person invest in medicine being cheap if they can buy it at a high cost when they need it, and why would they pay for the world to have food when they themselves have access to as much of it as they want?

There is no direct, instant gain or satisfaction for them, aside from being viewed as a hero, which I'm surprised doesn't incentivize billionaires more often (aside from outlier like, for example, Bill and Melinda Gates who supported this exact video). We should invest in others being better off so that their kids can be more educated and influential in this world, but a rich person who's 40 years or older (as in, most of them) isn't going to gain from such long-term investments because they won't be around when that change is made.

This is a great argument for why we should redistribute wealth somewhat, but unfortunately this argument alone will not make the world a better place. Until there is some sort of change in how we redistribute wealth in the developed world, this argument will fall on deaf ears among those who need to hear it the most.

From what I've seen, the problem isn't trying to improve the quality of life for others, it's getting those others to accept the effort even if it means going against literal millennia of cultural bias.
People from Western civilizations can go in to third world countries with the intent of raising those countries up to Western standards, but how soon do the inhabitants go back to the "old way" because they either don't understand or care about Western mores and values? A church group can go build an automatic well in some distant African village and feel like the accomplished something, and for a while they did, until the automatic well stops working and the villagers lack the tools, parts and expertise to fix it and they're right back to where they started before the well. How many times have NATO allies went with armies to Middle Eastern countries with the intent of deposing a dictator and bringing peace and stability to the area only to see another dictator rise up and start the sectarian violence as soon as the armies leave?
It's all well and good to WANT to improve the world, but often times the problem isn't the intent but the execution; without a long term plan of investment and action to ensure the improvements stick and become ingrained in the local culture, you're just trying to put a bandage on a gaping wound that needs stitches.

I disagree...it's still a zero sum game in a lot of areas.  There is only so much land on Earth for people to live.  We are hundreds of years away from being able to ship significant amounts of people to Mars.  The Earth is too crowded.  We've seen that as China industrialised and modernised, its people now have the money and resources to demand a standard of living more on par with the west (such as eating more meat, having more luxury consumer goods).  This has led to further degradation of this environment as the newly middle class Chinese want more meat (which is more resource-intense to produce than plant-based food), they now demand more energy and raw materials, driving up the cost of raw materials (such as iron, coal, oil) as the Western countries must now compete with an ever-growing demand from China.  There is only so much clean air, and as developing countries industrialise they pollute more and more of it.  Maybe one day we will have Star Trek replicator technology, but for now it is not positive sum.
