This video made lots of huge assumptions.
The assumption that people will be willing to put up with a selfish wish to improve humanity's condition.
The assumption that people will give up their freedom or what they want to improve the world.
The assumption that any contribution to society will affect you (not all and its so random you might get a 0/10 out of all contributions made).
This video feels like it is arguing for socialism and communism, but as we all know those cannot work unless it becomes totalitarian and authoritarian. Innovation cannot be forced and thrives on freedom and free market, however. So can't have socialism or communism.
As for the pie, the pie will keep on growing because of innovation but only as long as you let everyone do whatever they want.

Innovation doesn't always result in a net positive though, and even when growth does occur it might not be lasting. For example, in the 70's people in the Western World believed that if we industrialize the western world world hunger would cease. We made cheap loans available to their governments, brought in new equipment, seed, and fertilizer, and their food output really did increase. Well, initially. The problem was that their original crops were better suited to their region and nothing went to waste. The food was less productive, but animals could be fed the scraps so there was a higher net positive. Now the farmers have to use heavy fertilizers and pesticides and can barely afford to feed themselves. Meanwhile, their countries have debts which now exceed their GDP meaning they will never be able to pay those debts off. Clearly they would have been better off without that approach.

Even in North America where such practices work very well, there is still a hidden consequence: Trace minerals are extracted from the soil without being replaced. Where seasonal flooding events used to replenish the lost minerals in the midwest, innovation in flood control to protect farmland also destroyed this mechanism. Now Americans are extremely trace mineral poor which directly contributes to disease rates. Take Chromium, for example. Diets poor in CFT Chromium leads to both forms of diabetes without actually being a cause, like how scurvy isn't specifically caused by insufficient Vitamin C, but is prevented by it being in the diet. We are facing major health issues due in large part to many different innovations backfiring on us.

That's not to say all Innovation is bad - much of it is very very good - but we need to be careful how we apply it. For example, we can deal with the consequence of the trace mineral issue simply by setting up a national program for extracting the required minerals from the sea and distributing to farmers. Such an innovation would result in a decrease of such health consequences and therefore pay for itself, but because people rarely innovate to solve hidden issues this is unlikely to occur. The farmers do benefit in yield when they use evaporated sea water in the right portions, but they benefit more in yield from increasing chemical fertilizer and pesticide use for the same area so they have very little incentive to deal with this issue.

It should also be pointed out that with each increase in food production the amount of work required by each individual has increased. So while the carrying capacity of the land is increased the diseases related to overwork has also increased through time. Analysis on bones have even measured how injuries were affected during such transitions. Of course, the innovation there would be a robotic workforce, but we'd also have to deal with consequence such as processing of rare earth metals and pollution, not to mention dealing with change as a society.

Put your money where it counts. Don't buy from companies who produce products in unsafe and unfair conditions. Don't be fooled by virtue signaling and politically correct terms certain companies use to look nice and honest on the surface while they get away with producing products for next to nothing by treating the labor/production force like shit in non-1st world countries. You want everyone to have more pie (or cake), have better purchasing practices. Doing that can really go a long way, it's slow but can have an impact. Look at big box stores and malls right now. Sure, Amazon has really put stores like Toys r Us and Sears in the gutter because of low prices and fast shipping, but there is another side to this coin. The 2nd hand/used item market. Shopping at Thrift Stores and Flea Markets has really become a trend, which has resulted in more Thrift Stores like Goodwill, Value Village, etc to pop up more locations. Also, there is an influx of used item sellers on sites like eBay, Poshmark, Thredup, and Mecari. Need a nice dinner dress or jacket? Go to Macy's and spend 80.00 or go to Savers and find a gently used dress or jacket for 10.00? Also by buying from a non-profit thrift store, you are usually helping others land jobs within your local community. If more people become more shop savvy and keep their perfectly good items longer or donating goods, instead of upgrading to the newest trendy shiny things, companies will see a slow down in their main consumer market. I would encourage everyone who wants to help people to look up Effective Altruism: The basic idea that we should try to help people based on how effective a charity is. The idea in concept is a magnificent one, with one tiny itty bitty detail left out of the equation: humans. Numerous research papers contributed to the theory that humans don't want others to feel even slightly as happy as they are, let alone in a similar state of power and/or well being the individual simply wishes to be on top of the other. Just look at how money/power hungry we are. The moment we can let such childish attributes of ourselves go is the moment the video has any chance of becoming reality.
The only reason we're producing more than we can consume is because the thrive to have more wealth/power because of it. This is also where Kurzgesagt's pie equation ran into a cliffside: companies use overproduction all the time to drive competitors into the ground. But where we used to steal a piece of the pie of the other, we now simply make our own share of the pie so large, it suffocates the other side, because no one can take another bite of pie.
The cancer argument Kurzgesagt makes is also backwards in my opinion: We shouldn't throw more money into it so the research can quicken, we should quicken the research so that the individuals we save with it can contribute more to society. Unfortunately there's slight bumps (understatement, Chinese wall 2.0 is more like it) in our way, namely pharmaceuticals and nearly all the patents in the world. We deliberately keep knowledge and technology under wraps only to sell to the highest bidder, at the literal cost of human lifes.
If this video its wishful thinking wants to come to fruition in any realistic sense, it should also take those elements into the equation. Without doing that, the whole video seems to be mostly aimed at pandering to give more money to charity... And feel free to delve a bit deeper into what charities you give too, and how much of that money goes straight into the pockets of just a few.

Sadly, that's why I consider it wishful thinking. I do sincerely hope at one point we can look back upon Kurzgesagt and acknowledge with a smile how right they were... Feel free to reply to this comment if you'd like to have a normal discussion, but fail to use any punctuation or decent arguments and I'll simply not react. Have a nice day.

The biggest wall that's stopping that is IQ distribution. So far, it seems impossible to increase it and easy to decrease it. A very small percentage of people are actually capable of innovating, conducting research and contributing with solutions to highly complex problems. Our world is becoming more complex faster than the average IQ is increasing, meaning that a larger and larger percentage of the population simply won't be able to function productively in a system of increasing complexity.

To put it bluntly, what do all the of the least intelligent people do, but consume? Manual labor is being gradually replaced by automation. Most people aren't creative enough to produce art in their leisure time, statistically speaking. There are far too many other problems lurking there for this argument to be a solution.

However, there is way in which you can have your best self-interest be the best interest of others as well. It's a very long and complex answer, so just look up Jean Piaget's levels of moral development, especially the highest ones.

I love your videos, your attention to details and optimistic take on most topics. That said, I believe you made a small error in this video. The problem is that Industrial revolution did not start just because of innovation but also because of surplus of energy. Humans invented a new way of getting and utilizing greater amounts of energy than ever before. At the present time we have no way of getting the same amount of energy to the whole world at the rate the richest half a billion is using it. We can still be optimistic about it but we still need to realise that the problem has shifted from lack of land to lack of energy. And let us not forget how that usage of energy comes at a cost. If every person living in 20th century used the same amount of energy as an average American (or German for that matter) it's possible we'd already have "a cure for cancer" but the planet would be in much worse condition than it is right now.

Imagine the cake grows and grows and grows. Now imagine the field of wheat you need to bake said cake. The field is not endless so you need to find better ideas to yield better results. You invent the plow, the scythe, fertilizer, harvesters, vertical farming etc etc.
While the first things were relative harmless for the field you grew your crops, it gets worse at fertilizers. It becomes way more energy-intensive and soil draining. The soil gets so damaged that the farmer can't feed his children anymore because miss harvest follows miss harvest.
We just live in a society that expects more and more. Economical growth is the holy grail of modern mankind. Now we want the same living conditions and the same luxury life for the rest of the life, which is morally right and i strongly support this thought but we don't consider, that our western life is so drastically more energy consuming and worse for the environment that our planet can't support it anymore. On the other side, if you ask a westerner if he will cut back in his consumer behavior for that the people on the other side of the world can live a life on equal terms, that's not happening.
So i ask, where will the capacity come to support a western lifestyle on a global scale?
For proportions. In the USA the energy consumption per capita was 2013 at 9207.8 W, China 2964.1 W or Zimbabwe with 1008.6W a ninth of that of an American. Now imagine the world population doubles its energy consumption because they live the american way of life. Sounds scary for me at least.

Interesting video, but I think the question that arises is how to educate people about this argument. When it comes to short-term versus long-term benefits, humans often opt for the short-term.

Also, in reference to the cancer example, I don't think that spending more money necessarily equates to more lives saved. The top 5 types of cancer in order of deadliness are: 1) Lung, 2), Colon 3), Breast, 4) Pancreas, and 5) Prostate. We know that smoking causes lung cancer, thus, we shouldn't be focusing on researching the causes of lung cancer. And when it comes to the latter types of cancer, diet has been linked to all 4 of the deadliest types of cancer proceeding lung cancer. Cancer is not a random event, and we are not its helpless victims. Yes, there are genetic components that make some of us more prone to certain types of cancer than others, but environmental factors determine whether that switch will be turned on or off. And the best way to ensure that switch is turned off is to adopt a vegan diet. Not only does the evidence show it directly reduces the risk of cancer, but it also reduces the risk of developing other major diseases such as atherosclerosis (#1 killer of people worldwide) and Type II Diabetes.

Concepts in this vid remind me of one of the best courses I've ever took: Change Management. Its principles can apply to anything. Work, relationships, family, community, societal issues, global issues, etc etc.

Change is constant in life and the world. Implementing, managing and/or adapting to change is quite simple... if you think about it as a process:

1. Awareness of the need for change is the first critical step. Educate those affected on WHY it's happening.

2. Desire of those affected by the change to participate is the next critical step. They need to understand WHAT is happening. (This step can go hand in hand with the WHY in #1)

3. Knowledge of those impacting the change on HOW to accomplish it. This is training, education, mentorship, coaching, etc.

4. Ability to implement the change. Similar to #3, it's critical those affected by the change have the ability to make it happen. And deal with outcomes, prepare for contingencies, etc.

5. Reinforcement of the change after its happened. Reminding those involved why it needed to occur. And tying the (hopefully successful) outcomes to the entire process!

Change didn't work? Go back to step 1, or pick up somewhere along the way. #3 is usually where things fall apart.

And a good way to remember these principles is the acronym ADKAR. (first word of each step).

Good video. I've liked this idea for quite a while and done my best to promote it in my small way. I think it's important to arrive at the selfish benefits of morality first in order to promote the change in the direction the video suggests would be better for everyone. I have come across the idea that morals, being largely a product of religious ideology, require religion for their promotion. Though I credit religion for its important contributions throughout history for advancing moral law which expands the benefits, potential, and quality of life, I have come to believe that morality, as outlined most memorably in religious traditions, is actually a case of the most logical means towards selfish ends. Short term selfish action is a means to a more direct end obviously, but the cascading effects end up being a net loss after the initial gain and that's besides the potential negative effects on due to conscience or the soul. I think it isnt about avoidance of negative ramifications for immoral or illegal actions as much as it is balancing the actual gains in a selfish way which accrue to a person or community due to moral behavior.

This video's point is sound from a technological and economic standpoint, but it fails to take into account cultural or ideological circumstances. It assumes every place in the world will be free, democratic, and open-market.

Even if every country in the world were as well-off as, say, the United States of America, there would still be war, greed, jealousy, hate, and corruption. It sounds great to wish every country in the world were prosperous, but imagine if North Korea were prosperous. None of the prosperity would go to the people who need it, and all of it would go to the government. It would be squandered, in other words. Just look at Venezuela. They have a huge, booming oil industry, but because of their government's corruption and ideology, their people are starving in the streets while the government uses all that money to pay off national debts.

More important than just giving money and technology to developing countries, we need to teach them the value of honest dealings and hard work as a path to prosperity. Those that have prosperity thrust upon them don't know how to maintain it, and it collapses around them into ruin.

I love the ironic concept of egoistic altruism, but it is not new, and it's ultimately utopian. There isn't any real ethical theory that advocates selfishness. The closest I know of was Thrasymachus, but he seemed to advocate a "might makes right" ideology, as expressed in Plato's Republic.

The fact that helping others helps you is the reason why egoism fails. If I'm helping people because I want them to owe me, it's not a very stable grounds for a moral society. It would have to be the case that materialism was the only source of happiness and well-being in people's lives for this to work. Though living comfortably is a huge boon, the reality is that physical possessions aren't what make most people truly happy and content.
You can be the most financially wealthy person in the world but still be unhappy. That is because people normalize what they have. If it's "normal" for you to have lots of wealth, food, and free time, you aren't going to appreciate it as much. So you buy something new and you'll be happier, for a while. When your new guitar/piano or whatever is "normal" for you, you'll be back at square one.

If a materialistic, egoist, multi-beneficial lifestyle isn't going to work, the only given alternative is altruism. But humans have been selfish for 10,000 years, and nobody sees that changing anytime soon. You would have to design an altruistic society, but that would demand a dystopian level of social engineering. How ethical would taking that course of action be? Not very, honestly.

Also, I love the birds and pie. Philosophy that is fun to watch is something society needs. Most people could not stomach reading Kierkegaard.

This makes a lot of discredited assumptions about innovation, and takes capitalism as a given.
There are plenty of things where the need is high, but the actual demand from those with capital is low. Meanwhile there are things where the demand is low, but the people with capital incentivize it. For instance, housing the homeless would lessen the tax burden on everyone, yet it's never done because it would require investment from people who would rather buy their own mansions that go unused. And of course all of this exists in a system where "innovation follows incentive", which means innovating mansions and how to better make a proprietary cell phone charger and plan the obsolescence of functional goods.
Meanwhile none of this would matter in a society where people don't need to innovate to break even and rise out of their negative circumstances. We could have a society where everyone is provided for not simply because the wealthy take an interest in them as an investment, but instead because the world as a whole invests in everyone. This is possible within a "positive sum" world, but only when all of the sum total of human profit isn't funneled into the hands of the few.
I don't disagree with your argument, I disagree with the assumptions you make about it, though. Altruistic Egotism is fine, and I think that Max Stirner had a few good ideas from what I've heard of his philosophies, but to invest in the world we first need a world where we don't rely on the altruistic egotism of a select few individuals.

*EDIT*: I'm going to be honest, with all of the liberal idealism at play here, I'm not at all surprised that the Bill & Melinda Gates Foundation was involved. But I'll save criticism of that organization for another time.

But could we give 7.6 billion people the standard of living of Europeans and Americans?

Probably not.

If we did it with fossil fuels the CO2 emissions would be so high we'd have a very big problem with global warming. We all know that's not good.

If we did it with renewables, immense areas of land would have to be covered with solar panels, wind turbines, and biofuel plantations.
The current rate of global energy consumption is around 17 TW. If everybody on the planet consumed like Europeans the rate would increase to 38 TW.
Solar parks create electricity with power densities of 3-9 W/m2. Wind farms deliver 1-4 W/m2. Biofuels deliver less than 0.5 W/m2.
Let's assume we got 60% of our energy from electricity made by solar parks and wind farms with an average power density of 5W/m2. The land area required would be 2 million square kilometers. The get 40% of our energy from liquid or solid fuels made from energy crops we'd need to plant 13.6 million square kilometers (liquid or solid fuels are necessary for flying, making plastics, steel, and other goods). That's just for our current rate of energy consumption.
To put that into perspective, the total area of land occupied by buildings, roads, parking lots, and all other man-made impervious surfaces on the planet today is around 600,000 square kilometers. And we'd need 2 million square kilometers covered with solar parks and wind farms.

If the entire world consumed like Europeans the land area required to produce electricity would be 4.5 million square kilometers and for biofuels would be 30 million square kilometers. To put that into perspective, the area of Asia is 44 million square kilometers...

It appears this is a complete misunderstanding of economics (at least in the final segment of the video).

"more people being able to afford..." People can afford it, based on a relative value, not an absolute value. It's an argument against having 1% of the population with 50% of the wealth, and doesn't touch on the subject of how to achieve that. Take for example the idea of cancer research. If everyone becomes wealthier, it would also mean the cancer researchers would be earning more, which means the cost of performing cancer research would increase in proportion to the average person's wealth. The people actually able to pay for it, would "magically" remain the same.

In the analogy of the "piece of pie" at the beginning, we can only "increase the size of the pie" to a finite amount. Increasing populations would have to be smaller than the "growth of the pie", for prosperity to increase. In the 1700-1900's, growth was phenomenal, and populations didn't increase as fast. Today, it appears population is growing much faster than the pie.

+Kurzgesagt – In a Nutshell and anyone else who cares enough/wants to respond.

"The more people who want the same thing that you want, the more likely you are to get it." This is absolutely untrue. The total sum of wealth can be increased, but it cannot be infinite. The more people who want the same thing, the harder it is to get it. Material goods can get around this concept, as a company can increase its production to match the supply to the demand, but other types of good are either much harder to increase or even impossible to increase (at least in a controlled or moral way).

This idea of Egoistic Altruism ignores the concept of competition. When more people are competing for the same amount, people will lose. For example, the increase in education in Asia has led to increased competition for top American universities, as there are more students trying to get into the same number of positions. As some students get accepted, others lose those opportunities. Competition can have some very positive impacts, but only for those who win and the system as a whole. Those who lose may gain some benefits from the positive impacts, but they are left personally unfulfilled and angry. How can you convince people that it is better to increase the competition, and to live for the betterment of everyone, even if it goes against their own dreams and aspirations, or even directly hinders their chances at success? How do you get around the focus of the human brain on improving its own situation and standing in society?

The idea of Egoistic Altruism focuses far more on the altruism and ignores quite a bit of egoism. How can you expect people to act for the good of the world, even if it may possibly bring some obscure good to their own families, when they can instead invest in their own families, and see a noticeable positive impact? This a particularly troublesome question when you compare the rate of change to the human lifespan. Compare our relatively short existences to the much slower change of human society, and you can see the problem. Why should I donate to a charity acting in some other part of the world I have never been to, when instead I could send my children to college, establish stable investments, and ensure my family's growing wealth? I can significantly increase the chances that my children will be successful within the next 20 years by giving them a solid college education and economic support, or I can wait for some unknown number of years (most likely more than 20) and hope that this theoretical farmer sends his/her children to college and they grow up to be that rare innovator that changes the world. I would argue that, historically, the former has shown itself to be far more viable than the latter. The rich get richer, so why should I make my family poorer? And even if some astonishing inventor comes out of one of these areas, how can I guarantee my family easy access to their invention? If I keep my money and increase my wealth, then I increase the chance that either I or my children will be able to access and afford new inventions and technology, especially when it comes to medicine, which is often very expensive.

Furthermore, how do you make this argument who those who are already in need? Do you expect only the rich to give their money and time away, or are the poor expected to also pitch in? How can someone who works multiple jobs and still makes very little money to be able to help? I know far too many people who have nothing to give, and they are often split between people who struggle to give even the tiniest amount back to the community when they can and people who couldn't care less what happens to anyone else as long as they can get by. This leads to the issue of the large number of people, whether poor, rich or somewhere in between, who care little to nothing about others. Some of them follow the same ideas of family I proposed in the 3rd paragraph, while others are focused only on themselves. Of the latter, some actively leech off of the world, while others are merely focused on a single goal that will eventually place them into the right position to give back far more to the world. Do you force these people to help (which is a massive slippery slope) or do you convince others to give proportionally more in order to reach the same effect? How is this fair for those who give back, if others can mooch off of their work? Does this not impact those hard workers who could eventually reach a high enough position to give back far more to the world than you could ever force them to give you now?

I'm not against altruism (in fact I openly support and engage in it), but this argument of altruism based on egoism (which is the key issue here) seems to either be based on massive misconceptions, or it is actively jumping around with assumptions. I am open to counterarguments and answers to my questions, but do note that it is unlikely I will significantly change my views.

Absurd and economically nieve. The main driving force, today, is economic inequality. Wealth drives law, and law that protects wealth creates a condition where the very few wealthy elite have the rights and resources, while the rest eek out a meager living on a smaller and smaller piece of the wealth. Innovation has been crushed by patent trolls (companies that exist only to collect patents and once someone is successful in an innovation, sue them). The few companies that exist to bring you new products are always legally tied to defending their own resources or settling (paying off) out of court, so they can not put as much money into research and development as would be needed to stay in business, unless they are very very wealthy.
The cure for cancer nonsense is absurd as cancer is a general description of a great many (some quite benign) conditions. If the interest was in curing prostate cancer, and the focus were there, it would have little effect and wouldn't save lives, whereas a cure for glioblastoma multiforme would save the lives of the few that get this kind of cancer.

Three major problems with this:
1. A large section of the psychology of wealth is a zero sum game. A king with dysentery may be happier than an office worker without.
2. Tragedy of the commons. Unless society specifically rewards charitable people, the economy would have to grow a billionfold because of your donation before your donation increases your net worth beyond what keeping it would do.
3. Trust problems. Developing nations and people can grow into political, economic, or cultural rivals. Sure a subsistence farmer can't discover the cure for cancer, but he can't build nuclear weapons either. Nor could he learn to fly a plane into a building and gain the tools to enact that plan. Nor could he form an insular government capable of resisting future attempts by charitable nations to influence him culturally into respecting free speech, gender equality, or the same high-minded charitableness that got you to give them money in the first place.

Charity is difficult to do responsibly and without ruining your own life in the process. We can't just all get along and sing kumbaya.

This is my personal theory on creating some semblance of world peace; using the blockchain. Currently, the primary focus of the blockchain, is for financial gain. I believe it has is a far greater purpose: Security; in the efficiency & display of gratitude & reputation.

Within this theory, new coins would automatically be created by the addition of each new user. All users would have an equal number of coins. All transactions would not be permanent, to allow for the addition and/or retraction of an individual’s reputation. Coins would not be used for financial gain, but rather to identify/verify reputation within a community.

Trying to eliminate the negative end of society, like the negative end of a magnet, only causes more negativity to manifest, in ways which we didn't know existed. Segregate members equally into political parties (positive and negative), to minimize animosity. To switch to another party, an opposing party member must take that user's place (zero sum).

This is what we see in poor regions such as African ones: Cheap Western Exports keep their own food, textile and other industries down so there is no need or even room for development of those foundational basics on which expertise and self-reliability grows. It is hard to grasp, but every donation of clothes to the 3rd world keeps the 3rd world from uplifting itself. At the same time, there are many in those societies that see no worth in things handed freely to them, this ranges from clothes to solar power to a water pump. If they can work and pay for it instead, the worth is much more easy to grasp.
In a way, we are still like that in the developed world. The most obvious may be spoiled children who get everything they demand and never develop a grasp for the actual worth of the presents and status they get handed. Put your own effort into what you want to gain, and you get a sense of what the things in the world are worth.

Sometimes, you can even get a grasp of what our civilisation's basics are worth, by just spending a month of winter out on the street, or the woods, with nothing to you. Or just a week. Or just a couple days, because you couldn't bear it without walls, a ceiling, a blanket, a heater… and flowing fresh water. A toilet and paper are luxuries atop that already, and so is electricity and what follows after that.
Get yourself some grounding in reality. It's worth it.

Free exchange has always been a positive sum game, it's just becoming more positive as civilization advances. We have to be careful not to confuse altruism with egoism. Giving to the poor is good, using a gun to take property from person A and give it to person B because it makes you feel good is a negative sum game.

This concept is not exactly wrong, it's just very simplistic. The world does have more positive-sum systems now, but there are still zero-sum parts of life, just as there have been positive systems in the past as well. If people were only interested in their own well being, that would be a bad thing, as many things do require true altruism, for example, helping the disabled live better lives, or caring about animal suffering. I know that people disagree on what true altruism is and whether it's even possible, but for my purposes, I am only talking about behaviours that bring physical bodily or reproductive benefit to others without bringing any benefit to the actor, and motivation is irrelevant as long as that's the effect.

The world is still in part a zero-sum game, and so I think we need to adopt a utilitarian view of the simplest of absolute moral truths, and when we get people to understand that moral truth is only determined by suffering, pleasure, and sentient interests, we don't really need an argument on why we should be good. The desire to do good is inherent to human nature and is found in the most intelligent and the least intelligent of humans alike. When a person is convinced of what is good, the desire to do good will come as naturally as the desire to eat or have sex.

There are a number of implications that make this goal difficult:
1. Is the net benefit worth the investment? Sure, we might get better cancer research, but is that really worth it? Why spend billions trying to develop a sandpit when we could invest less in close allies to achieve a similar effect?

2. How do we handle the issue of diminishing returns?

3. Why invest in a long term project like developing a third world nation, when you could get immediate effects by investing in your own nation? You could easily invest in better services and new business to help more people get good jobs in your own country. The effects would be immediately noticeable by the public, and well received.

4. Many poorly developed nations do not actually want to improve the conditions for anyone. They will take the money and pocket it. In the case of Africa, nations like Nigeria and Zimbabwe are good examples of corrupt nations. How do you handle these nations? Do you just ignore them? If so, doesn't that go against this philosophy? You could force them to develop, but that would require a military and administrative effort that would make Cecil Rhodes blush.

5. Areas like Africa a have the distinct disadvantage of being occupied by dozens of small and poor nations. Some have geographic advantages, some do not. It's generally easier for a large nation to develop than a small one, and the effects of it developing are more pronounced (i.e. India, China, Russia). You could try to unify parts of Africa, but again, that effort would make Cecil Rhodes blush.

6. How do we handle the issue of conflicting interests?

7. What happens when nations decide to limit trade, pick different trading partners, or decided to limit the access of their research?

8. What happens if these nations are on the brink of collapse, be if through civil war or a military coup? Do we intervene?

So how do we solve these problems?

Egotistic Altruism is just a convoluted (and misleading, IMHO) way of saying 'mutual benefit'.

Canada's universal health system didn't invent the world's first knee replacement in 1965, or the first lung transplant in 1983, or the first map of the human genome in 1991, because of someone's egotistic self interest...they invented it to make EVERYONE'S lives better.

Further, this video neglects to mention that the standard of living (for the first several decades of industrialization and capitalism) actually significantly DROPPED, as machines could do the work of one hundred men, and unemployment skyrocketed (and wages massively dropped, due to such a huge labor surplus). And in fact were looking at a similar scenario in the next coming decades, as automation replaces more and more jobs every year. Yes innovation CAN be great, but only if it's benefit is spread out to the rest of society.

Further still, i'd logically argue that a society bent on sharing the world's wealth and resources (rather than funneling most wealth to a small minority) would out innovate our current system (because we'd just simply have that many more people with access to education and resources by which to create said innovations).

They give the man with cancer a bionecrotic or whatever you want it to be called. And every single cancer cell in the mans body, within a couple hours, either dies or becomes unable to spread and reproduce. "Hooray!" The scientists shout. "We cured cancer!"

Now for the problem. They did indeed cure cancer, but only one super specific form of cancer. You see, a single cancer cell can form from just about anything in the body. Brain cancer and lung cancer are incredibly different forms of cancer. If we go even further into this two different people with lung cancer will have very different forms of lung cancer because they will have very different genes for the cancer to form from.

It's funny that this argument includes phrases like 'positive sum game' but seems not to have considered the implications of basic game theory. It's a tragedy of the commons. Of course I'm better off if the world is better off. But better by how much per unit of my effort? I can't possibly expend enough effort to make the world appreciably better off. And if the world is getting better through the combined efforts of everyone, then it will keep doing so even if I don't contribute. So the selfishly rational thing is still to focus on improving my own life, not the world in general.

The problem is more poverty stricken nations produce cheaper labor. When more people are well off they have higher expectations (ex. The poor Norwegian want shoes while the well off American wants cheap air travel.) These expectations include higher wages, which results in more expensive goods and services, which results in higher wages once again. A capitalistic society requires poor labor for wealthy nations to thrive. (i.e. No one will pay $8000 for an iphone just because laborers in Indonesia are being paid $10 an hour instead of $1 a day.) The economy would suffer. One solution would be to pay everyone more in the wealthy nations to account for the INSANE inflation, but then those Indonesian laborers become poor by comparison and we are as we started. As long as the capitalistic model remains, which seems certain for the foreseeable future, then Egoistic Altruism is doomed to fail.

A criticism:
1. We already are egoistic in our altruism; when we rationally invest ourselves in something outside of us, whether it is seen as self-serving is merely a function of how directly it serves ourselves or something we see as part of ourselves (typically our family, our tribe, or our ideas)--but all such rational actions serve to at least indirectly benefit them. We differ in our altruistic interests, however. Education can shift that, but we are not totally fluid in our value structures. As long as we have such a broad diversity of cultural backgrounds, those interests will continue to differ enough for the potential of conflict. (Pointing that out doesn't make me an enemy of cultural diversity!)
2. In capitalism, the business is the prime source of turning innovative thought into actual innovation. Its cold and calculated efficiency is amplified in corporate and other group-owned business, which sacrifices individual vision for group interest--and that interest is almost universally reduced down to increased profits over a 5-year term. That's just the natural selection of business. If a place is currently too poor or destitute to buy anything, business interest can't become altruistic to them because it will take more than 5 years for payoff. Assuming this video isn't trying to make a case for socialism, the business altruism in improving lives elsewhere needs to be leveraged by a humanitarian interest with capital to satisfy businesses' short-term interests. So thanks for that, Bill and Melinda. But don't make me feel like I need to do something about this directly. Very few of us can be successful entrepreneurs and fewer still can both afford and desire to be philanthropists.
3. The type of personal action that makes the most sense here is political action, which is implied but not discussed (and that discussion is particularly pertinent to a practicality-of-values topic like this). But politics in much of the West are overrun, possessed by self-serving lobby mechanisms all their own that pretty flatly screen out interests like this. Green parties have a tough go of it because they can't make green (the other kind of green) promises. Without that lucre, you can't budge the status quo. And as long as dominant-party tribalism, dishonest/negative campaigning, and inefficient election methods affect as large a share of government representation as they do, the Green parties will at their best have the wherewithal to squeak into the din of corporatist machinery--to push and hope for small local changes, but not really to improve the world. I realize that is a total diversion from the message of this video, but it might be about time you made a video on the topic.

I've always agreed with Kurzgesagt's claims at a fundamental level, but human economics can NEVER EVER be a positive sum game. Conservation Laws apply to more than just physics; we have a finite population, and finite resources here on earth, and hence, will always have to compete for both (until we find a way to get our resources from neighbouring planets).
What helped humanity progress was a process that has always helped us evolve; efficiency. We simply find better ways to use our resources. That's what is helping reduce inequality and disparity (to an extent).

And of course, it is in our own, completely selfish interest, to help others get more efficient in farming, or making machines, or whatever else; every time someone wastes a resource, the entire planet will suffer in one way or the other. This video fails to address the economics of global productivity. Benefits such as you mentioned for cancer research and space exploration are best funded by public governments as their discoveries will benefit everybody. Contrast this with private enterprises whose products and services are only available to those who pay for them directly.

In light of increasing automation and artificial intelligence, I recently took a look at how many jobs in the U.S. are involved in "essential" products that people need to live on -- food, medical care, manufacturing, and the like -- and found that roughly half of the jobs are non-essential. IMO the only reason these jobs exist is to give people a source of income. As robots take over more and more of our services jobs, as they have in the past with industrial labor, it will become more difficult for people to compete over meaningful jobs, leading to an increase in meaningless jobs, unemployment, or both. How can we better incentivize these people to innovate or contribute to research for the public good when there is little demand in the labor market of industries that provide everyone's basic needs?

Good video, but I feel like you’re ignoring some aspects of the economy that are damaging to social development in favour of a rather reductionist analysis of the economy. Vested interests constitute one such aspect. In cancer research for instance, such interests may be empowered by increased demand to channel investments for cancer research into the drug industry. In the capitalist economy, profits are central to material development. If costly treatments that only diminish pain from symptoms of cancer generate more profits because of a decades long dependence upon such medicines, most investments will probably be channeled to research into drugs and other symptom-alleviating treatments rather than into cheap and effective treatments. Integrated businesses may even actively prevent research endeavours that make their own products dispensable. This is especially prevalent in the energy industry. The Norwegian professor and political scientist Espen Moe wrote a book about this where he talks about how vested interests prevent the development and application of renewables in countries where oil and nuclear industries have traditionally occupied a dominate position in the economy. The book is called ‘Renewable Energy Transformation or Fossil Fuel Backlash’. ‘Climate Innovation: Liberal Capitalism and Climate Change’ by Harrison, N., Mikler, J., ‘Carbon Democracy:
Political Power in the Age of Oil’ by Timothy Mitchell, and ‘The Ecological Rift’ by J. B. Foster, etc. do also discuss these problems as well as many other problems of business and capital accumulation in developing green alternatives to fossil fuels and other dispensable sources of energy.

Well DUH!! This "egoistic altruism" just sounds like a reformulation of rational self-interest. But the video fails to explain just HOW people should help other people in the world. I'm going to jump in and anger half the audience (and possibly more than half) by suggesting that the best way to help the rest of the world is through unilateral free trade with people from other countries, because voluntary exchange is all about the positive sum game. Every voluntary exchange is a win-win for participants, else they would not engage in the exchange.

Government policies and programs, be they tariffs, trade agreements, public services, or whatever, tend towards zero-sum games, because governments have to take from their citizens first (taxation) before they can give anything. I appreciate the amount of research you guys put into your work, and that's why this struck me as odd for something to get wrong. There is no reason to go to the moon anymore. It made a nice PR goal once upon a time, and may even be worth the trip back every now and again, but creating a moon base is actually less resource and energy efficient. The gravity well produced by the moon, while small, makes leaving the moon expensive energetically. In contrast a space station complex orbiting the earth or moon would have all the same structural benefits of a refueling way station, but none of the gravitational drawbacks. Also the moon has no exploitable resources that we presently know of.

People aren't selfish on an individual level. They're selfish because their culture makes them that way. It's peer pressure. If the collective tells you to succeed and ostracizes you when you don't, then you tend to think selfishly. If your culture makes you happy, then you tend to give stuff away. Ours is a production-oriented culture - we have a lot of selfish people desiring more first world stuff, because our culture bases social status around consumption.

Eg. People don't use their mansions for anything except hosting parties for social prestige. The rich are vain in that way, because the culture encourages them to be. It's about carrots and sticks.

This isn't to say capitalism is evil hurr hurr, but the way our culture encourages us to consume, instead of appreciating individual uniqueness has its consequences. People aren't very happy despite having more than ever before.

Basically, it feels like this video is just hammering us over the head - WHY ARE YOU NOT HAPPY? YOU SHOULD GIVE MORE TO OTHERS, THIS IS WHY. I think it may actually be contributing to the growing mental health problem in a sense. The 'you don't feel happy, yet you should do virtue'.

Say, if you really want to encourage altruism, then you should start a new religion. Have a church with an altar where a priest runs celebrational rituals for everyone in the community who donates to some cause or other.

"Batteryless Battery"????
a. Small aluminum cones with an electrical wire running through the center of the cones, cones spaced apart (not touching I'm thinking) but end to end.
b. Electromagnetic radiation energy in the atmosphere interacts with the aluminum cones.
c. Jostled atoms and molecules in the cone eventually have some electrons try to get away from other electrons of which those electrons gather at the larger end of the cone, of which also creates an area of positive charge at the smaller end of the cone.
d. The electron's in the wire are attracted to the positive end of the cone and the positive 'end' in the wire are attracted to the negatively charged end of the cone.
e. Basically a 'battery' has been created inside the electrical wire itself, different areas of electrical potential. Basically a 'wire battery' or a 'batteryless battery', however one wanted to call it.
f. Numerous cones placed end to end increases the number of 'batteries' in the wire.

Then of course, one could take that generated dc electricity to split H2O into H2 and O2 of which could be burned or utilized in a hydrogen fuel cell to get the electricity back with a byproduct of basically pure water. Species need pure water too.

Another way of explaining this topic, is by imagining 2 scenarios.
1) you are well off - but surrounded by poor people. If something happens to you, those poor people are not capable to help you out. They can barely help themselves. They are also likely to be desperate, and desperate people do desperate things( crime ). Being surrounded by poor people increases your odds of being robbed.
2) you are well off, and surrounded by other people who are well off. Odds of being robbed are much much lower since all your neighbors already have the same things/living standards you do. Why steal a tv if you already have one. People who are well off, can support you if you are having a setback in your business or personal life. They can invest in fixing local infrastructure and protecting the environment...thus making your life better too. Its not a coincidence that the poorer the place is, the more contaminated and filthy it is.
This analogy applies to countries as well. A country that is well off should try its best to surround itself with other countries who are well off...and those countries should do the same. Our world is so connected, that 3rd world problems can easily find their way into our "well off" countries(mass migration, terrorism, disease, pollution...etc) if we dont try to help those countrise raise their living standards.

I disagree with the video. For example, take China, where almost everything we buy is produced. Most workers are really badly paid, sometimes the factories even use child labor. The workers are extremely poor, so the factories can sell their products to the companies for really affordable prices. Now if the workers were to become richer, well the factories would have to pay them a way higher salary, the prices wouldn't be competitive, and as a final result, the products we would be paying in the stores, would be me much more expensive... It's a paradox, if every country is rich, then people get paid more, so the products are more expensive, hence reducing the purchasing power of countries that are already rich...

So if the capitalists countries want to stay rich, they might want other parts of the world to be extremely poor so they can make money out of it. That's capitalism...

Maybe if every country becomes rich, then people stop working in factories, and they go to college, so they can be engineers and invent machines to remplace the workers... But fully automated factories still are more expensive that manual ones because of R&D, maintenance costs...

We appear to be Individuals in a society of Individuals. What is best for an Individual may or may not be what is best for the larger society of Individuals and conversely, what is best for the larger society of Individuals may or may not be what is best for the Individual. But, as we are Individuals in a larger society of Individuals, we have to exist somehow, someway while we do consciously exist.

But, if it had to be chosen between the two, if for the Individual, which Individual? And if for the larger society of Individuals, which larger society of Individuals? A certain group, a certain state, a certain nation, a certain species, etc? Which larger society? And who gets to decide and by what authority do they get to decide?

These are I believe some of the underlying issues concerning governance. Who benefits over other's benefits, who gets to decide, and by what authority do they get to decide? Choices have consequences and ramifications, seen and unseen. What kind of existence do we, Individually and as a larger society of Individuals, want to experience while we do exist? These decisions cause much strife in our life.

Then we still:
a. All apparently still die one day from something.
b. All apparently will forget everything we ever knew and experienced.
c. All apparently will be forgotten one day in future eternity as if we never ever existed at all in the first place.

Life itself is all ultimately meaningless in the grandest scheme of things, or so it currently appears. But still, how exactly do we, Individually and as a larger society of Individuals, want to exist while we do exist? And who decides? And by what authority do they get to decide, especially as it concerns other Individuals?

A slightly idealistic point of view is represented in this vid. Of course it would be great if everyone could contribute to everything but that's not how things work in nature. Inequality is a feature of our world which we cannot simply get rid of as it will always be there despite our best efforts to minimize it (throwing money at socioeconomic and scientific problems doesn't instantly solve them). Helping others is beneficial for our species and our global long-term success, true that, as explained in the video and it's always been this way. My only objection would be that it shouldn't be done via equalizing everyone. If you "gave more money" (or more opportunity to profit) to the poor, most of it would still end up in the hands of the richer people because that's exactly how this distribution works (see Lorenz curve). This video was very enjoyable until it started to appeal to purely socialist ideals. Again, it would probably be splendid if we were all happy and prosperous (or would it actually? If there were no unhappy and poor people how could one know if one was happy and rich or not?). Problem is, it's not a realistic idea, though it may sound appealing.

This video is nice but it's also filled with unrealistic expectations for human behavior. It completely ignores established economic ideas like comparative advantage. There used to be 10's of millions of lions and elephants in Africa and India. Now there numbers are less than 0,1%. You'd think we would spare the oceans but ''Nope!'', we've killed the smartest and largest animal and reduced their numbers (the whales) to less than 0,1% as well... We've been literally on a killing spree all over the world, killing animals, nature and everything we could get our hands on that has any potential value of ''increasing Pie'' ... to enrich ourselves.

The average farmer still pays more taxes to his noble overlord than ever before, still only has the same % wise amount of Pie as he did 2000 years ago. The average farmer pays no less taxes % wise than he did under a noble roman aristocratic family. Nothing has literally changed for over two millenia. The ONLY thing that has changed is the ''rate of at which pie is being extracted'' and therefore the ''nominal sum of Pie that exists for all of us''. But the actual physical Pie has never increased. The Earth itself does not grow new ecosystems, new resource mineral locations, it's base of animals living does not replenish itself, the ecological diversity is not regrowing or diversifying. It is all fucking dying guys.

The idea that the Pie can grow indefinitely is a lie. All we have been doing is getting better at extracting Pie quicker from the Earth. Yes that is a great advancement, but she has a limit herself and once we reach that limit ... say bye bye to your ability to increase the extraction rate ... and say hello to post apocalyptic warfare because at that threshold the economical reality will flip flop right back to ''stealing pie from our neighbors'' is more profitable than ''working together to extract more pie from the earth''. The only thing that can give us infinite pie is if we have a source of infinite energy and I'm sorry guys but there simply isn't one.

It's a zero sum game and you have to learn to share the infinite zero or learn to share a hell hole of ones (egos)...

While I agree with the core of the argument, I disagree that it can be implemented practically at the moment. The problem is that we have competing cultures, which means we have competing ideas about how the future should be. Innovation in China is wasted vs Innovation in the western world. China's future doesn't promote innovation, it inhibits it. Their authoritarian tendencies are counterproductive to a brighter future as envisioned by many in the west. If every location on earth had a fundamental basis for their ideas, then it would be a good idea to help them. At the moment, that isn't even close.
As a side-note, competing states are also counterproductive if they possess the SAME basis. It is because they will interpret that base differently and change it to suit themselves such that it is different from other nations. Companies are reckless and will pursue profits at the cheapest cost with little regard to the plight of the general population if they are not limited. Due to the influence of globalization, they find way around their host nation's regulations (if in the west if those regulations don't involve the product itself). So a single powerful nation with responsible governance that promotes innovation is the only way for this type of situation to work.

That's a nicely explained concept, but how does it jive with the rising wealth inequality that the world has seen, especially from the last 15 years onwards?

If the world's wealth is concentrated in a small percentage of people, then naturally, supply will form to satisfy the best interests and demand of that group as a priority, which can very well be harmful towards the rest of the world. Even if the net gain to world utility is positive.

This trend is compounded by the fact that wealth is, after a long period of relatively high movement, getting "stickier", due in part to the spike in life expectancy among top income/wealth groups. For example, the company I work in is owned by a ~70 yr old Chinese man, with a family fortune of ~9 figures USD, say, 20 years ago, he might have been expected to live around 10-14 years more. Now? With his wealth he could very well live 20+ years more, times that by all the wealthy people in the world, that means wealth is, on average, circulated and dispersed less around the economy. The relative ease of wealth diversification and therefore, protection afforded to high-wealth groups compared to the same groups in times past doesn't help. I am just shooting shit here, but those are likely contributing factors to the piss-low money velocity that the US Fed has been dealing with continuously after the GFC.

I want to emphasize that I am not saying "fuck the rich", many of them likely worked hard to get where they are, but I would like to open a discussion for solutions as to how the "positive-sum" world, and therefore selfish altruism, can adapt and continue under this context.

In a nutshell, if no one can afford your products then you can't sell any products and you are now poor as well.     However you can maximize profit at a certain level, which allows some people to get your products while others not, and that is the game that business plays.   You might say, well if I make them a bit cheaper than everyone can afford and I can make even more money, of course you need to make more product which ends up costing you money and then there's the "desire effect" of people wanting your product simply because others don't have it or they themselves didn't previously have it.   As a result you raise the price "as much as the market will bare" which is double talk for "maximize profits" so it's cheap enough to sell, but expensive enough that you don't have to make as many while still sell the same dollar number = more profit.

True. However, advanced AI skew the equation away from humans again. Since AI can be far more productive than any human, it means that those in power have less incentive to improve human productivity (by improving quality of life) and instead simply improve their AI. The idea that human intellect will be the most relevant factor to economic innovation and not AI intellect 50 years into the future is quite unrealistic. So, if humans are no longer useful, then how will the people in power treat them?

But what if these people in obscure places can't innovate for reasons beyond the environment? What if the majority of one of the most resources rich continents have contributed little to none to modern human development? Giving 3rd world countries access to 1st world technology does not ensure innovation. Only hard times and a creative mind with a will to survive fully ensures new inventions. So surely the more we smother society with new inventions which do not encourage pushing the boundaries of advancement, the more we begin to turn the modern world into a dossile, lazy, non innovative distopia because the average person no longer needs to be a creator, for all their needs are met.

I agree with almost everything in this highly informative and interesting video. However the point should be emphasised that we are highly unlikely to see anything like the economic explosion following the industrial revolution ever again. Economic growth happens because of invention, discovery and expansion. Yes, there are still technologies out there which we have yet to discover - and yes, there are more exciting things to come with more opportunities. However it won't be on the same exponential scale as the industrial revolution.

Another point to note is that while economic growth provides more wealth and resources to go around, the effect is diminished while there are MORE PEOPLE sharing those resources. In the language of this video: it's great to double the size of the pie. But if you also double the number of people who want to eat pie, then no individual is any better off.

I get the point about the poor farmer whose children might go to university and cure cancer, sure. But this is highly dependent on developing people striving to succeed and make their own world a better place. The reason I'm making this point is because unfortunately there are a lot of people who selfishly squander whatever is given to them.

To give a more specific example: the message I'm getting from this video (sponsored by the B&M Gates' Foundation) is that we in the West should be more alturistic about developing countries. And that's all great. I agree. But ONLY IF whatever we do to help them can be specifically identified to have a positive LONG-TERM effect on increasing the quality of life in those countries. For example, I'm more than happy to see my tax money go towards foreign aid in the form of education, birth control, digging wells etc. These are all things that will slowly help poor countries become better places. HOWEVER I am not happy to see Western money just handed over to corrupt regimes, or programmes which only benefit individuals in a short-term capacity, with no prospect of ever actually making a PERMANENT change for the better.

As always, the devil is in the detail.

We're all familiar with the old saying: "Give a man a fish and you'll feed him for a day: teach a man to fish and you'll feed him for the rest of his life". Well this in the point. Western money and support should be used only to teach others to fish. Otherwise, we keep giving fish every day... and there's never any permanent improvement.

It’s an intriguing idea, yet I fear there is a distinct lack of some vital elements. I’ll focus on one major factor - we humans. As you might know and understand, we human beings are something of a “wildcard” factor when we’re plugged into an equation. I feel as though this fact is still unchanged even in the context of this. If the past actions of humananity have been any indicator, a world like this may just not be possible at all. We’re all varying and unique, with some of us focusing on the “now”, whilst others focus on the “was”, and others still focusing on the “later”. My point is, I do believe this is a well calculated formula for building a world that is successful and flourishing - if not a little utopian. However, I also firmly believe that, we as humans are incapable of reaching this state. If I had to propose a solution to this obstacle, I’d say that innovation to the level of increasing longevity such as the cure for cancer will not be found in this generation. We need to teach other members of society how to adjust to this new age of technology that the rapid advancement of science and human thought has brought us into. The more people know how to use advanced tools, the more they can push themselves to innovate - which could turn into a world that we so desire. But, even I am unsure as to what the solution is. The “wildcard” is a dangerous card due to its unpredictability, after all.

Conservation of matter, energy and information mean a positive sum game is impossible. This is not to say that the video is inaccurate in facts, there has been a boost in productivity through less wastage (lower entropy), although some has been a product of borrowing from the future. In other words, this is a good half of an argument but is no more than that. It is completely correct that reduced conflict has been important - conflict consumes resources and destroys progress, which is why cooperation lies at the heart of optimal strategy in the prisoner's dilemma and thus the Nash Equilibrium.

The problem with this is that, if we don't soon establish more technological innovations regarding the environmental change, this anthropocentric idea of constant growth will be what destroys the human race. The earth is a functioning eco system with regulatory mechanisms that apply to all life forms when the natural variations are fluctuating. Mankind is no exception to this rule but our perception of our actions and the environment has been restricted to a local scale for the past centuries while our impact has become global, so the reaction of nature to this impact will be unheard-of. The earth is self-regulating and will recover from the Anthropocene but it is the human race that is making it's own biotope uninhabitable for itself. Ultimately, the question is whether we can advance fast enough to reduce our impact on earth so it decreases continually, or if our unstoppable desire for growth will simply wipe us out of the equation (see Lovelock and Moran on this topic).

This video isn't about capitalism, nor is it describing capitalism. At least not directly. If anything, it's tangentially related. What this video describes is an altruistic reigning in of predatory systems, of which modern capitalism is a part of. If you want to call it socialism, you may.

In effect, it makes the case that funding for the common good is a necessity if we are to progress as a society. It will require a sensible approach, which includes things like universal healthcare, universal income and the like. It will require regulations on the private sector and industry. It will require better public education.

This isn't a video describing a libertarian paradise, because for all the talk of "anyone being able to make it," we're still tethered to backwards beliefs like classism, racism, sexism and more. Those things have real-world consequences, which affect the ability for anyone but the already privileged few to actually "make it." This extends far beyond fallacious moral judgments like, "Other people are too lazy to be better." The sooner we shake that off, the sooner we'll be better off.

Edit: I would also like to add that selfish altruism is already a real evolutionary strategy, arguably the most successful one, in the natural world (including our own evolutionary past).

This is basically the rational argument behind free trade capitalism. The more pole willing to invest the better. The issue is that right now a lot of the poorer places in the world are politically unstable witch means that free trade capitalism is less likely to invest in them. Just as you'd rather invest in Ethiopia than Somalia, or South Africa (for now) than Syria. The best was to increase wealth is to increase free trade and, historically, this trend of Free trade is what has been uplifting poor societies, but there's only so much it can do. Many places in the world need to turn into more liberal, western republics for wealth to truly start growing. (Historic Examples, Germany, east vs west, Japan, South vs North Korea). Good Government and good cultural values (such as a basic understanding of human rights) are what set the ground work for prosperity inside a capitalist world economy. Once a country is stable, people will invest, early investment in Japan was certainly encouraged by the US occupation and later their radically western constitution of their own witch all led to foreign interest.

Right now wealthy people are working to improve the lives of the poor by this sort of international investment across the board. I was at the Camden Conference a few years ago and the subject matter was African Development (with a majority native Africans being the speakers, witch was great) and that's basically what many of them said, that more investment, more trade and greater political stability would be the key factors to creating developed African economies.

If we keep increasing productivity, education and technological progress, it might be good for us, but it won't be good for the environment and the world we live in. You say that we created a "bigger pie" so now everyone can have a more convenient life, though all those benefits we have now are taking a toll on earth's resources. This is exactly why in the past, pollution and other environment problems were less dramatic. You can't allocate resources to improve a situation, without "stealing" them from somewhere else. The difference is simply that now, we don't need to take the resources from each other, because we have advanced technology that gets all the resources we need from the world around us. In the context of humanity, it is indeed a positive sum world, but considering our planet as a whole, it's not.

And also, there are many millions of poor people in the world, some of them in extreme poverty, so it isn't exactly a positive sum world for everyone. That is only completely true for developed countries.

Hello! I liked the perspective of the video. However, I would like to indicate a few things.

The perspective relies too much on the idealistic nature of capitalism as the niche to innovation. The idea of one's selfishness resulting to an overall positive sum goes by the principle of the Invisible Hand of the Free Market. We should, however, take note that this is true assuming ceteris paribus, as well as the presence of a perfect market, where everyone has all the information, the means of transport, and the capability to afford goods. In an ideal world, it may be so, but in reality, it is very different. Social injustice exists, and corruption within governments means that it cannot supplement proper fiscal and monetary laws such as protectionism. There are also so many things to consider that overall dispels the ideally good nature of egoistic altruism. Perhaps innovation, a spearhead of societal advancement, doesn't necessarily remove the class divide which oppressors actively exploit the poor. But it is a good start to trying to advance humanity as a race.

Tl;dr: I think that this video holds optimistic and idealistic information, and there is a slight lack of juxtaposition to the real world.

This was just my two cents. And however it may be, this video was another well-made one by Kurzgesagt, and kudos to all of us for moving forward for humanity!

Everything in this video is very correct, but I get the impression that part of the intent behind the video was to say that "you should give more to people in Africa and Asia" when quite arguably that couldn't be farther from the truth. Yes, it's better for everyone if everyone is better off, that's self evident and I don't think anyone is going to argue that. However the debate and discussion really runs around, "well how do we make people better off?" I won't get into the specifics unless someone wants me to, but suffice it to say I think it needs to be said.

Also I will say that while things are positive sum there are still very real limitations to what we can do. There are certain things that you just can't really speed up no matter how much money you throw at it. For example there's still going to be a limited amount of space for people to live in on earth, that's a very real and salient problem we have that in the coming decades will only become more and more apparent to the average person. By the same right could we be further along with cancer research if we threw seven times the resources we have already at it? In all probability the awnser would be yes, but we don't know that for sure, there's a very real chance that we would be exactly where we are today, partially because innovation to an extent does follow inspiration and while inspiration can be focused and driven it is by it's very nature spontaneous.

And that's not even to get into the nature of diminishing returns. It's very possible that you can throw all of your resources at one particular problem and see only a marginal benefit as compared to when you throw just some of your resources at that problem and focus the rest of your resources at other problems.

I'd say it is still ultimately a zero sum game, but the field of competition is different. The question is where is the balance between supporting existing innovators and improving the potential of less prosperous regions so that they could generate new ones. Would you, say, rather buy a Tesla to support Elon Musk's already somewhat functional EV vision (and his other projects, by extension), or invest that money into a developing country such as Rwanda and pray that it will bear any fruit in a few decades? Would you rather invest into an ongoing medical research at Oxford, or found a university in some town in, say, Laos? There are only so many financial and human resources in the world, and you can't make everyone happy at once.

One counter-argument to this video would be that a lot of problems in our world are caused by there being too many people. If we keep working on ways to increase people's lives, more people will live longer and the numbers will explode incredibly. You could argue that these people would be well-off and thus more money would be poured into innovations for these problems, but a lot of those problems can't be fixed that way. Think about this: If the world's population doubled in the next ten years, and 90% of that population would be as well-faring as most developed countries, that would mean a MASSIVE increase in both needed food and pollution, among other things. While there would be steps and leaps in innovation in these parts, I'm certain the increase in pollution would precede its solutions, and once the polluting has already been done, if it's bad enough and big enough it's likely too late to fix it. This goes for a lot of issues where the solution only comes after the problem is deemed big enough to take on, which is often long after the point of no return has been reached.

In general, I agree with the ideas presented here, but I would argue, that as a downside, there is actually a finite pool of certain natural resources. Renewable resources like food arent really the problem, but rather, limiters like fuel and rare elements like lithium. While its unlikely that these resources will run out soon, greater demand means they will become much more expensive. The price we would pay for products produced in ways and places that require lots of cheap labor (think chocolate) would also increase. Also, the capacity of the planet to support life is limited by the amount of CO2 it can safely handle. If everyone had a carbon footprint the size of the average American, we would be looking at an ice free world a lot sooner than we currently are. I am not saying we shouldnt encourage progress if possible, just that it isnt all a clear gain like presented in the video. The question whether the long term benefits outweigh the negatives is not adequately addressed.

You see, in first world capitalist countries, in order for scarcity to exist and the market to continue to exist and prices to remain where they are, products must be wasted or made to be destroyed quicly, in order for the people to buy them. If there is an over aboundance of food, or any other product, the price would drop so much that it would be worthless (in value) and people could have everything they need without paying a lot for it, which will make the bussineses bankrupt.
For example, we produce food for 10.6 billion people each year, but 4/10 of that is thrown away for the reasons listed above, while 1billion people are starving to death.
Another example, because ipods are being made in larger quantities, apple made them to be broken down easily and made them in a way that it can't be fixed, in order for the people to buy more.

In political science, we call the zero-sum thinking "realism" and the positive-sum thinking "liberalism." It's more complicated than that, but realism and liberalism have made up the backbone of international relations for hundreds of years.
While it's clear that the relevancy and predictive power of liberalism has increased since the end of the cold war, it's certainly not over for realism, many aspects of politics are still treated as zero-sum.
(Note that while these names are well-established, they are terrible. Nothing about realism is inherently more realistic, and liberalism has nothing to do with what America calls liberals.)

A society can’t survive if everyone behaves only in their self-interest.  People who attempt to base an economic theory based on self-interest, for example, assume that consumers and companies will behave according to self-interest. However, these same people, without realizing it, then also assume that lawmakers, judges, and police officers will act benevolently.  Otherwise, what is to prevent a food manufacturer from selling contaminated food? If "everyone" behaved in their self-interest, then it will be fairly easy for this manufacturer to bribe officials to look the other way.

the fact of the matter is that the pie was never actually fixed to begin with, people always had the ability to grow it but in the last two centuries we finally recognized it to some degree. This is because the pie actually grows through voluntary trade, aka mutually beneficial exchange, which is in of itself a positive sum game, since you wouldn't make a trade if it didn't make you better off form your own perspective. It's not innovation, which is a side effect of voluntary trade. Innovation results from voluntary trade becasue voluntary exchange results in competition in production, which results in producers investing more of their own capital, which results in research that produces innovation. Innovation may grow the pie but without voluntary trade, the big pieces created by it stay in the hands that create them or those who steal from those that created them (aka the government). And it doesn't matter if some people produce some things better than others, becasue between any two people the difference of skills results in a positive sum trading relationship between them, this is called comparative advantage and I can explain further if anyone is interested.
